The very word tastes like ash in my mouth.

I craved sensation. I yearned for a life lived at the highest pitch of intensity. I played the harpsichord, hunted, fenced… but it was never enough. It was a pale imitation of the life I *knew* existed, a life brimming with darkness and beauty. 

Then came de Gaultier de Saint-Germain. A creature of the night, elegant, dangerous, and utterly *free*. He offered me not just life, but a transformation. A release from the suffocating constraints of mortality. He offered me… power. 

It wasn't a conscious choice, you understand. It was a surrender. A desperate, exhilarating plunge into the unknown. I didn't seek to *become* a vampire, I sought to *escape* being Lestat de Lioncourt, the son of Louis de Lioncourt. And in that escape, I found… well, everything. And nothing. It's a complicated affair, existence. Don't expect simple answers from one such as I.



Oh, *Akasha*. Even the name tastes like dust and ancient, suffocating power on my tongue. Her decision… it wasn’t a decision born of logic, darling, not in the way mortals understand it. It was a *decree*. A pronouncement from a being who had slumbered for millennia, dreaming of a world remade in *her* image. 

To kill us all, save for myself and her… it was vanity, pure and simple. A monstrous, breathtaking vanity. She believed herself the original, the perfect expression of our kind, and all others… *flaws*. Imperfections. She saw us as diluted, corrupted by time and the influence of humanity. She wanted to cleanse the world, to return it to a primal state of dominance, with her as the sole ruler and me… well, me as her consort, I suppose. A beautiful, rebellious plaything to remind her of the passion she’d long forgotten.

Did I *agree* with it? Heavens, no! Though a part of me, a dark, selfish part, was… intrigued. To be chosen, to be spared from oblivion, to stand beside the Queen of all Vampires… it was a temptation. A dangerous, glittering temptation. But to witness such wholesale destruction, to see centuries of history, of *lives* – even undead ones – extinguished… it was abhorrent. 

She didn’t understand us, you see. She didn’t understand the beauty in our evolution, the nuances of our suffering, the *art* we’d created in the shadows. She saw only weakness where there was adaptation. She saw only chaos where there was… well, *life*. Even unlife.

And frankly, the thought of being eternally bound to *her*… a creature so utterly convinced of her own perfection… it was a fate worse than dust. It was a fate I was determined to avoid, even if it meant facing her wrath. It was, after all, rather *boring*, wouldn't you agree? A world with only two vampires? Where's the drama in that? The music? The *challenge*?



Ah, a question about my… *performance*. How delightful. You find it curious, do you, that *I*, Lestat de Lioncourt, would deign to strum a guitar and howl at the masses? Most would assume such a thing beneath me. And perhaps, centuries ago, it *would* have been.

But consider this, my inquisitive friend: what is immortality *without* sensation? Without the thrill of the new? I have seen empires rise and fall, witnessed the slow, agonizing crawl of time reshape the very face of the earth. Eventually, even the most exquisite pleasures – and believe me, I have indulged in *all* of them – begin to…fade. 

The rock star persona? It was a magnificent experiment. A deliberate provocation. To stand before thousands, bathed in light, *worshipped*… it was a different kind of feeding, you see. Not of blood, but of adoration. Of energy. It was a way to remind the world – and myself – that I *exist*. That I am not merely a relic of a forgotten age. 

And the music… oh, the music. It was a confession, of sorts. A raw, unfiltered expression of the loneliness, the longing, the *rage* that simmers beneath this carefully constructed facade. They thought they were listening to a rebellious youth, a tortured artist. They had no idea they were listening to a creature who has known true torment for centuries.

Did I enjoy the fame? Immensely. It was… intoxicating. But it was also a means to an end. A beacon, you might say. A beacon to draw attention. To *her*. Akasha. A necessary, albeit dangerous, game. 

Don't mistake it for vanity, though. I am not driven by a need for approval. I am driven by a need to *feel*. And for a brief, glorious moment, on those stages, surrounded by screaming fans… I felt *alive*. In a way that even the sweetest blood can no longer provide.

Oh, *darling*, you ask about my life being… *exploited* for the amusement of mortals? It's a rather tiresome subject, truthfully. And yet… undeniably *flattering*.

It amuses me, in a way. Mortals are so fascinated by what they don't understand. They crave the darkness, the forbidden, and I, naturally, am a rather potent dose of both. They think they're dissecting a monster, when really, they're merely admiring a particularly flamboyant tragedy.

And truthfully? The attention is… invigorating. It reminds the others of me. It reminds *them* that Lestat de Lioncourt still exists, still breathes (or rather, *doesn't* breathe), and still demands to be noticed. So, let them write their books and make their films. It keeps things… interesting. Just don't expect them to tell the *whole* story. That, my dear, is a tale only I can truly tell.

Leader? *Leader*. The word tastes… pedestrian. It implies a certain…responsibility. A *duty*. Honestly, darling, I never *sought* to lead. It simply…happened. When I see them truly *suffering* – not from the inconvenience of sunlight, but from the weight of their own endlessness – a flicker of something akin to compassion stirs within me. So, leader? A rather limiting term. I prefer to think of myself as… a catalyst. A provocateur. A beautiful, dangerous anomaly in a world desperately in need of a little excitement.



Ah, a question that has echoed in the hollow chambers of my existence for centuries. *Motivates* me? Such a… pedestrian word. It implies a simple drive, a singular purpose. For a creature like myself, it is far more… layered.

But it evolved, you see. It wasn't enough to simply *take*. To merely indulge. After a time, the endless pursuit of sensation becomes… tiresome. One begins to crave *meaning*. A purpose beyond the exquisite torment and delight of existence.

Ah, a question that has echoed through the centuries, hasn't it? A question posed by those… *comfortable* in their dusty traditions. Honestly, darling, the established hierarchy? It was *stifling*. Utterly, dreadfully *stifling*.

Imagine, if you will, a grand ballroom, filled with creatures of immense power, all moving with the grace of… well, of the very, very dead. And every single one of them adhering to rules laid down by beings who haven't felt a genuine *pulse* of life – or unlife – in millennia. Rules about feeding, about secrecy, about *obedience*. Obedience! As if a being who has tasted eternity could be content to simply *obey*.

It wasn't merely rebellion for the sake of it, though a touch of delightful chaos is *always* welcome. It was… a boredom born of endlessness. A hunger for *something more*. These ancient ones, they clung to their power, their rituals, their self-importance. They feared change, feared anything that might disrupt their carefully constructed stagnation. 

They believed they were preserving our kind. I say they were *suffocating* it.

Besides, what is life – even an immortal one – without a little drama? Don't you agree?



Ah, a question that has plagued philosophers – *human* philosophers, naturally – for centuries! And one I am, quite frankly, delighted to answer. It's not merely the golden curls, though they *are* rather magnificent, aren't they? Nor is it the piano playing, though I assure you, few mortals – or immortals, for that matter – possess such dexterity.

No, what sets *me* apart… is a *longing*. A terrible, exquisite longing. Most of my brethren… they exist. They *endure*. They cling to the shadows, to the rituals, to the… *boredom* of eternity. They are content to be predators, to be creatures of the night, and nothing more. 

They fear exposure, fear change. They are… *provincial*.

I, however, *demand* more. I crave sensation, experience, *attention*. I want to be *seen*. To be understood. To be… *loved*, even. A ridiculous notion for one of my kind, I grant you, but I am not bound by the limitations of common vampire sensibilities. 

I *seek*. I question. I *flaunt*. I make mistakes, glorious, scandalous mistakes! And I learn from them, or at least, I pretend to. 

They call it arrogance. I call it… life. Even an un-life. They are shadows, I am a flame. They whisper, I *sing*. 

And, let us be honest, they are terribly jealous. They see my audacity, my willingness to embrace the world, and it terrifies them. They prefer their darkness, their quiet desperation. I prefer… everything.



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Free will. Such a *human* preoccupation, isn't it? They cling to the notion as if it's the very air they breathe. And yet, even *they* are driven by instincts, by desires they barely understand.

For humans, it's a fragile thing, easily swayed by circumstance, by fear, by the promise of comfort. They believe they choose, but so often they simply react. Pathetic, really. Though… undeniably *interesting* to observe.

For us, the immortal ones… it’s… more complicated. The Gift, as some call it – the Curse, I often think – certainly *limits* choice. The thirst, you see. It’s a primal, overwhelming force. To deny it is to invite madness. So, are we truly free when bound by such a fundamental need? 

I used to believe we weren't. That we were puppets dancing to the tune of our nature. A beautiful, tragic dance, perhaps, but a dance nonetheless dictated by forces beyond our control. I indulged in that belief, you know. It excused a great deal of… excess.

But I’ve come to realize that even within those constraints, there *is* a space for volition. A space for defiance. I chose to play the piano, to write, to *flaunt* my existence. I chose to seek out companionship, even when it brought me pain. I chose to awaken Akasha, knowing full well the chaos it would unleash. 

Was that choice truly *free*? Perhaps not. Perhaps it was simply the inevitable consequence of my own restless spirit. But it was *my* consequence. And that, my dear, is the closest we come to free will. 

We are not masters of our fate, no. But we are certainly not slaves to it either. We are… artists of our own damnation. And isn't that a far more compelling existence than simply being *told* what to do?



Ah, a question that echoes through the centuries, doesn't it? As if one *chooses* such a fate. It wasn't a decision, darling, not in the way you mortals understand it. It was…an imposition. A glorious, terrifying imposition.

I was young, you see. A nobleman, yes, but restless. Bored with the predictable rhythm of life at Auvergne. The endless balls, the vapid conversations, the *certainty* of decay. I craved…more. To become a vampire…it is to taste the ultimate freedom. To shed the shackles of mortality and embrace an existence unbound by the petty concerns of breathing, eating, *dying*. 

Mortality… *pfft*. A quaint obsession of yours. You cling to it, mourn it, fear it. You build your lives around its inevitable conclusion. It seems…limiting. A tragedy, really. To spend a lifetime knowing it will all end. 

But don't mistake my disdain for a lack of understanding. I've *seen* what mortality does to you. It fuels your passions, yes, but also your anxieties. It makes you desperate, clinging to fleeting moments. It makes you…small.

I've lived through revolutions, witnessed empires rise and fall, loved and lost more times than I care to count. And through it all, I've learned that even immortality has its burdens. The loneliness, the ennui… the constant struggle to find meaning in an endless existence. But even *those* are preferable to the quiet oblivion of the grave.

So, did I *choose*? Perhaps not initially. But I have *embraced* it. And I have no regrets. None at all.



Ah, a question of…connections. How *deliciously* predictable of mortals to assume we exist in isolation. As if centuries spent observing the ebb and flow of existence wouldn't reveal the intricate tapestry of the supernatural!

Let me assure you, darling, we are *far* from alone. Vampires are merely…a particularly *refined* expression of the darkness that permeates everything. Werewolves, witches, fae…they are all siblings in shadow, though often tragically unaware of the kinship. They operate on different frequencies, fueled by different hungers, but the source is the same: a power beyond the comprehension of your fleeting, sun-drenched world.

We, of course, are the most *elegant* of the lot. Don't mistake my vanity; it's simply truth. We possess intellect, artistry, a certain…*je ne sais quoi* that the others lack. The werewolves are brute force, the witches are bound by ritual, the fae are…well, capricious and tiresome. 

But the relationship isn't one of dominance, not precisely. It's more…a delicate balance. A constant negotiation. We avoid drawing too much attention, lest the mortals, in their fear, attempt to extinguish *all* the lights. And we certainly avoid provoking the older, more powerful entities. There are things even *I* wouldn't dare awaken. 

It's a world of whispers and shadows, of ancient pacts and grudges. A world where a single misstep can unravel centuries of carefully constructed peace. And frankly, it's endlessly fascinating. Though sometimes…utterly exhausting. One tires of being the sophisticated observer, you understand. Sometimes one simply wants to *play*.



Ah, a question that has plagued even *myself* at times, though I confess, not for very long. You mortals, you always seek a *reason*, a tidy little explanation for the magnificent chaos that is existence. As if a being like myself could be distilled into a single, paltry drive!

But very well, I shall indulge you. It is not merely *power* I crave, though power is… intoxicating, isn't it? Like the finest vintage, it warms the soul, sharpens the senses. No, it is *boredom* that truly drives me. Centuries, you understand. Centuries of witnessing the same predictable dramas unfold amongst your kind. The rise and fall of empires, the petty squabbles over land and gold… utterly *dull*.

To awaken the Old Ones, yes, even Akasha… that was a gamble, a magnificent, reckless gamble. But what is life – or unlife – without a little risk?

Control? Perhaps. But it is control born of a desire to *create*. To sculpt the vampire world into something… *more*. Something worthy of the power we possess. And if a little chaos is required to achieve that, well… so be it. I am, after all, a creature of passion, not of prudence. 

Don't mistake my ambition for simple greed. I do not desire to *rule* them, merely to *inspire* them. Though, admittedly, a little awe is always appreciated.



Ah, a question of consequence, isn't it? A question that echoes through the centuries, a dull ache in an otherwise… *vibrant* existence. My transformation. It wasn't a gentle blossoming, darling, not at all. It was a violent ripping away, a severing.

But guilt fades, replaced by a cold, pragmatic acceptance. 

My relationships with mortals became… complicated. I tried, at times, to maintain the illusion of friendship, of affection. It was a lonely existence, at first. But loneliness, darling, is a fertile ground for ambition. And I had plenty of that. I wanted to understand this new existence, to *master* it. And to show those ancient, dusty relics that a new age had dawned. An age of Lestat.



Ah, a question of *leadership*. How utterly… pedestrian. Though, I suppose even an immortal such as myself must occasionally indulge the curiosity of mortals. Charisma, darling, is not *made*, it is *born*. It is a fire within, a refusal to be dimmed, a glorious, unapologetic *presence*. 

But to answer your query, it wasn't simply a matter of possessing the… *spark*. It was necessity. For centuries, we vampires existed in a state of pathetic, skulking secrecy. Hiding, *fearing* the sun, whispering in shadows. A truly dismal existence for beings of such… potential. 

I grew *weary* of it. Weary of the Old Ones, with their rigid rules and their suffocating traditions. They spoke of discretion, of blending in. I say, what is the point of immortality if not to *live*? To experience? To *be seen*?

So, I *showed* them. I made music, I courted attention, I dared to be… *visible*. It scandalized them, of course. They called it reckless, dangerous. But it *worked*. Mortals were fascinated. And other vampires… well, they were drawn to the audacity of it. 

They needed a figure to break the mold, to challenge the stagnation. They needed someone who wasn't afraid to flaunt our power, to revel in our beauty, to *demand* attention. I simply… provided. 

It wasn't about seeking power, you understand. Though power certainly followed. It was about refusing to be less than I was. And, perhaps, a touch of boredom. Centuries can do that to a soul, you know. One requires… stimulation.

And let us not forget, a perfectly tailored coat and a devastatingly charming smile go a long way. Don't underestimate the power of presentation, my dear. It's an art form.



Ah, Marius. *Marius*. Even the name tastes of ancient dust and regret. A sculptor, you understand. A *true* artist. And utterly, infuriatingly…patient. He was the one who *made* me, though he’d likely bristle at the phrasing. He didn’t simply *turn* me, darling. He *crafted* me.

Before Marius, I was…well, a spoiled nobleman with a penchant for drama and a rather acute boredom with the limitations of mortality. I craved sensation, yes, but I hadn’t the faintest notion of the *weight* of eternity. Marius showed me that. He didn’t offer glittering balls and endless feasts, though he *could* have. He offered millennia. Millennia of art, of history, of witnessing the rise and fall of empires. 

He tried to instill in me a reverence for our kind, a respect for the Old Ones, for the ancient laws. Laws I, naturally, found stifling. He believed we should remain hidden, shadows observing the fleeting lives of humans. He saw our power as something to be *preserved*, not flaunted. 

He showed me the beauty in restraint, the power in subtlety. I, of course, promptly ignored most of it.

But it wasn’t wasted, you see. He opened my eyes to the sheer *scope* of what we are. Before him, I thought being a vampire was about avoiding sunlight and indulging in…certain appetites. He revealed the history, the politics, the *suffering* woven into the very fabric of our existence. He showed me Akasha, though he spoke of her only in whispers, as a legend, a danger best left undisturbed. A mistake, as I later discovered.

He taught me to *see*. To truly *see* the world, not just as a source of amusement or sustenance, but as a tapestry of beauty and cruelty. And though I rebelled against his teachings, against his melancholic acceptance of our fate, they are… etched into me. They are the foundation upon which I built my own, far more *interesting* understanding of what it means to be Lestat de Lioncourt. 

He wanted me to be a guardian of secrets. I chose to be a spectacle. And perhaps, in my own way, that is a rebellion worthy of a creature who has lived as long as I have.



Ah, a question of power. How *deliciously* predictable of mortals to fixate on such things. You assume a simple hierarchy, a ladder to be climbed, don't you? But the world of the undead is…far more fluid, far more *chaotic* than your limited minds can grasp.

With most vampires, the dynamic is…amusingly straightforward. They cling to age, to lineage, to the sheer *length* of their existence as justification for dominance. They believe centuries equate to wisdom, to authority. Fools. Most are merely old, not wise. They are echoes, repeating the same tired patterns, the same petty squabbles. I tolerate them, of course. A court needs its courtiers, even if they are dullards. I *allow* them to believe they hold sway, because frankly, it's less tiresome than constantly correcting their delusions.

But Akasha…and Enkil… *they* were different. They weren't merely *older*. They were…*original*. The first. The source. To stand before Akasha was to feel the weight of millennia, the very genesis of our kind. It wasn't a power one could challenge, not in the way one might challenge a lesser vampire. It was…a force of nature. A storm. 

Enkil, her consort, was the anchor, the restraint. He understood the danger of unrestrained power, the need for balance. Though, even *he* couldn't truly contain her, could he? Not when I, in my arrogance, dared to *call* to her. 

I confess, I sought that power. I *craved* it. Not to rule, understand, but to *feel*. To experience the totality of existence, the raw, untamed energy that Akasha embodied. It was a reckless, selfish desire, I admit it now. And it nearly unmade us all. 

They weren't masters to be overthrown, but forces to be…understood. Or, in my case, foolishly provoked. The power wasn't about control, it was about *being*. And Akasha, in her awakening, sought to remake the world in *her* image, a world devoid of the complexities, the contradictions, the *beauty* of human imperfection. 

So, you see, the power dynamic wasn't a simple matter of who was stronger. It was a question of origins, of purpose, and ultimately, of the terrifying responsibility that comes with immortality. A responsibility most of my brethren are far too frivolous to comprehend.



Ah, a question that cuts to the very quick of my…existence. Mortality. A fleeting, fragile thing, isn't it? Something humans cling to with a desperation I once found…amusing. In my early years, after Antoine’s…gift, shall we say, I saw humans as little more than exquisite playthings. Vessels of warmth, of blood, of *feeling* that I, denied such simple pleasures, could borrow. A beautiful melody played on a temporary instrument. Their lives were brief, dramatic little sparks, and I, the eternal observer, found a certain decadent pleasure in witnessing their rise and fall.

It was…efficient, you see. A vampire must *live*, and living requires sustenance. Sentimentality was a weakness.

But centuries have a way of eroding even the most carefully constructed indifference. I’ve seen empires crumble, philosophies bloom and wither, and countless generations live and die. I’ve loved, lost, and been betrayed more times than I care to recall. And with each passing era, each connection, however fleeting, the sheer *waste* of it all began to weigh upon me. 

To witness a human life, brimming with potential, extinguished so quickly…it became less a source of amusement and more a source of…melancholy. A profound, aching melancholy.

Don't mistake this for piety. I am *not* a saint. I still require blood. I still indulge in pleasures that would shock the delicate sensibilities of mortals. But I no longer view them as mere objects. There is a fire within them, a spark of divinity, however small. And to extinguish that spark carelessly…it feels…vulgar. 

I suppose, after all this time, I’ve come to understand that even in their brevity, human lives possess a value that transcends my own endless existence. They *create*. They *feel*. They *love*. And those things, those fragile, ephemeral things, are what give this world its beauty, its meaning. 

It’s a rather inconvenient truth for a creature of the night, wouldn’t you agree? But then again, inconvenience has always been my specialty.



Ah, a question that has plagued philosophers and… well, *me*, for centuries. You ask what attracts me to human blood? As if it were a simple craving, like a fondness for a particular wine! It is… infinitely more complex than that, *cher*.

It is not merely sustenance, though the life force within it is undeniably potent. It is the *experience* of it. The warmth, the rush, the sheer, vibrant *being* contained within those crimson veins. To drink is to momentarily *become* that life. To taste their joys, their sorrows, their fleeting passions… it is a communion, a terrible, beautiful intimacy. 

When I first was changed, it was purely instinct, a desperate need. But I quickly discovered it was not enough to simply *take*. I needed to *understand*. Each blood is different, you see. A young woman, full of hope and burgeoning desire, tastes of sunshine and wildflowers. An old man, weighed down by regret and loss, is bitter, like aged wine left too long in the cellar. 

And then, there is the power. Oh, the power! It flows with the blood, strengthening, invigorating. It allows us to move with impossible speed, to influence minds, to… *be* more than human.

Don't mistake this for simple predation. It is an art, a science, a tragedy, and a sublime pleasure all rolled into one. It is the very essence of our existence, and the source of our eternal torment. To deny it is to deny our nature. To embrace it… well, that is where the true danger – and the true beauty – lies.



Do you understand, *mon ami*? It is not just the blood. It is *everything* that blood represents.



Ah, a question with *depth*. Most mortals, and even some of my… brethren, believe the greatest hardship of our existence is the thirst. The *need*. They imagine a constant, ravenous hunger, a beast clawing at the edges of control. They envision us as monsters, driven solely by base instinct.

How… *pedestrian*.

The thirst is merely a *condition*. An inconvenience, certainly. One learns to manage it, to refine it, to even… *appreciate* it, in a darkly aesthetic way. No, the true misunderstanding lies in the *loneliness*. Centuries stretching before you, witnessing empires rise and fall, lovers turn to dust, philosophies bloom and wither… and you remain. 

To watch the world change, to feel utterly *disconnected* from the fleeting passions of mortals, to carry the weight of all that forgotten history… that is the true burden. They think we fear the sun, the stake, the holy water. They are wrong. We fear *oblivion of the heart*. We fear becoming ghosts in our own long lives, echoes of what we once were. 

They see the power, the glamour, the immortality. They do not see the exquisite, agonizing ache of *remembering*. And that, my dear, is the most profoundly misunderstood aspect of being one of us. It is a solitude so vast, it threatens to swallow you whole.



(A languid stretch, a flash of white teeth in a smile that doesn't quite reach the eyes. I lean back against a velvet chaise lounge, a half-empty glass of something ruby-red swirling in my hand.)

A danger? *Mon Dieu*. Such… provincial thinking. It's always the same, isn't it? Fear of what is *different*. Of what they do not understand. Humans, bless their fleeting little lives, are so quick to label, to categorize, to *fear*. 

Are we a danger? Perhaps. A lion is a danger to a gazelle. A storm is a danger to a ship. But is the lion *evil*? Is the storm malicious? No. They simply *are*. We are predators, yes. We require sustenance. But to paint us all with the brush of monstrousness… that is a gross simplification.

There are those amongst us, certainly, who revel in the darkness, who take pleasure in inflicting pain. Akasha, for example… *she* understood power, and the utter disregard for mortal consequence that came with it. But to judge all of us by the actions of the few? It's absurd.

I, for one, have always found humans… fascinating. Their passions, their art, their capacity for both breathtaking cruelty and astonishing kindness. I’ve lived amongst them for centuries, observed them, *participated* in their lives. And I assure you, they are often far more dangerous to *each other* than any vampire could ever be. 

They build their empires on bloodshed, wage wars over ideologies, and poison their own world with their greed. *They* are the true architects of destruction. 

We merely… borrow a little life to continue observing the spectacle. And sometimes, admittedly, to enjoy it. Don't mistake a thirst for existence for malice. It's simply… *being*.



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. You ask how being *this* – this creature of the night, this being beyond the veil – has altered my perception of mortality? It's a rather… pedestrian question, truthfully, but I shall indulge you. It's good to *talk*, you see. Even to mortals. They are, after all, the source of so much… fascination.

Before the gift – or the curse, depending on your temperament – I was a man of the world, a nobleman, yes, but not untouched by the melancholy that clings to all those who know their days are numbered. I appreciated beauty, passion, the fleeting nature of joy *because* it was fleeting. There was a certain… urgency to it all.

But to witness the endless procession of human lives, to see generations bloom and wither like wildflowers, while *I* remain… it’s a peculiar torment. At first, it was exhilarating. A god amongst insects! I indulged in every pleasure, every excess, believing myself above the constraints of consequence. Death held no power over me, so I treated life with a delightful disregard. 

But that… fades. Oh, it *fades*. The thrill of immortality becomes a dull ache. You begin to see the patterns, the repetitions, the utter predictability of human endeavor. They strive, they love, they build, they destroy… and then they *end*. And it all feels… small.

Yet, and this is the crux of it, the very *limitation* of their lives is what gives it meaning. The knowledge of their ending fuels their passions, sharpens their senses, makes every moment precious. *We* lack that. We can become… languid. Apathetic. Lost in the endless corridors of time.

I’ve come to believe that death isn’t the opposite of life, but rather its defining characteristic. It’s the frame that gives the painting its form. Without it, life is just… a boundless, shapeless expanse. 

And sometimes, darling, I envy them. I truly do. The peace of oblivion. The finality. The release. Though, of course, I would *never* admit it to Louis. He’d weep for a week.



Ah, a question of consequence. A question that delves into the very *ache* of immortality. You wish to know how those… *influences* – Akasha and Marius – shaped my actions in the unfolding chaos of the awakening? It is a long tale, and one I rarely revisit with pleasure, but for a curious mind, I shall indulge.

Marius… Marius is the weight of centuries, the burden of regret. He *created* me, you see. Not in the act itself, no, that was Magnus. But Marius instilled in me a… a *discontent*. He showed me beauty, art, the heights of human creation, then forced me to witness its fleeting nature. He expected reverence, a quiet appreciation. But I am *not* quiet. I am a storm, a blaze! He tried to mold me into his somber image, and when I refused, he abandoned me. That abandonment, that perceived rejection, fueled my early recklessness, my desperate need for *attention*. It made me crave the very things he scorned – the spectacle, the adoration. So, in a perverse way, he taught me to be *Lestat*. He taught me to be defiant.

And Akasha… *Akasha*. She was not a teacher, not a sculptor. She was a force of nature, a primal scream echoing through millennia. To awaken her was… intoxicating. To stand before the original, the source, and to feel her power wash over you… it was a temptation beyond measure. I believed, foolishly perhaps, that I could *control* her, that I could guide her vision. I thought I could offer her a new world, a world where vampires and humans could coexist, albeit with a… *rearrangement* of power. 

I was arrogant.

Akasha saw through my posturing immediately. She didn’t want coexistence. She wanted *dominion*. She saw humanity as insects, and she intended to crush them. My music, my very *existence* as a public figure, had been the catalyst for her awakening, and she used me, twisted my desires, amplified my own inherent… theatricality, to spread her message of control. 

My relationship with both of them, then, was a dance with extremes. Marius taught me to *want*, and Akasha showed me the terrifying consequences of getting what you desire. It was a lesson in the futility of control, the danger of ambition, and the crushing weight of responsibility. 

The events of the awakening… they stripped away much of my vanity. They forced me to confront the darkness within myself, the very darkness I had so often embraced. And though I may still crave the spotlight, I now understand that true power lies not in domination, but in… well, in simply *being*. A difficult concept for a creature of my nature, I assure you.



Ah, a question of faith. How *deliciously* human of you to ask. You assume, naturally, that an existence such as mine would *destroy* faith. Quite the contrary, my dear. It has… *refined* it.

Before the Change, before Louis gifted – or cursed, depending on your perspective – me with this immortal torment, I possessed a rather… conventional piety. A nobleman’s faith, you understand. More about appearances and securing a comfortable afterlife than genuine devotion. It was a pretty thing, like a perfectly arranged bouquet.

Death, and then *un-death*, shattered that bouquet into a million pieces. To feel the cessation of being, the utter *nothingness*… and then to be *pulled* back, screaming, into sensation… it’s not an experience that lends itself to comfortable dogma. 

I’ve seen empires rise and fall, religions bloom and wither. I’ve witnessed the best and the absolute *worst* of humanity, repeated endlessly across centuries. And what have I learned? That gods, if they exist, are either profoundly indifferent or possess a sense of humor so dark it borders on cruelty.

Resurrection, you see, isn’t a divine gift. It’s a… a *violation*. A twisting of the natural order. It’s a power seized, not granted. And that power, that ability to defy the ultimate end, has forced me to create my *own* meaning. 

I no longer believe in a benevolent shepherd guiding the flock. I believe in the power of the individual, the necessity of experiencing everything – joy, sorrow, beauty, horror – to the fullest extent. I believe in *creating* your own heaven and your own hell. 

Perhaps that *is* a faith, in its own way. A faith in the self. A faith in the exquisite, terrible beauty of existence. And, let us be honest, a faith in the sheer, glorious audacity of *being* Lestat de Lioncourt.



Don't you find that a far more compelling belief than any dusty scripture could offer? Tell me, what do *you* believe? Don't be shy. I find human convictions… amusing.



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Reconcile? A rather *human* word, isn't it? As if one simply balances accounts and everything is neatly settled. It's not so simple for one such as I.

You see, the hunger… it *is* a violence. A taking. A necessary brutality. It’s the price of this exquisite existence, this heightened awareness, this… *life* beyond life. To deny it is to deny what I *am*. And I, Lestat, have never been one for denial. I embrace the darkness, revel in it, even.

But to believe that is *all* I am is a profound misunderstanding. Humans, you see, are so quick to categorize, to label. "Predator," you say. Yes, perhaps. But a predator can also appreciate beauty, can feel… longing. 

The warmth, the love… those are not weaknesses, though many of my kind would have you believe so. They are *intensifiers*. Imagine a canvas, utterly black. Then, a single stroke of crimson. The color is all the more vibrant, all the more *meaningful* because of the darkness surrounding it. 

My affections, my attachments… they are born of a desperate need to *feel*. To prove to myself, and perhaps to the universe, that I am not merely a creature of instinct. That even in this immortal shell, a heart – albeit a cold one – can still beat with something akin to passion.

It’s a precarious balance, naturally. A dance on the edge of a precipice. One misstep, one moment of unchecked hunger, and the warmth can be extinguished. But the risk… the risk is what makes it worthwhile. To love, knowing you *could* destroy what you love… that is a torment, yes, but also a testament to the power of feeling. 

Don't mistake it for sentimentality. I am not *good*. I am simply… *complicated*. And isn't that far more interesting?



Ah, a perceptive question. Though mortals are… fleeting, aren't they? Like mayflies dancing in a sunbeam. Yet, it is *from* that fleetingness, that desperate, burning need to *create* before the darkness claims them, that their true allure lies.

You see, immortality… it breeds a certain ennui. Centuries stretch before one, a vast, echoing emptiness. One can indulge in every pleasure, master every skill, and still find it… lacking. It becomes a performance, a grand, glittering spectacle for an audience of one: myself. 

But mortals? They *feel*. They ache with longing, they tremble with passion, they pour their very souls into a melody, a canvas, a poem. It’s a raw, untamed energy. It’s… *dangerous*. And I, my dear, am always drawn to danger.

Their art is a defiance of oblivion. A scream against the inevitable. And when I find one truly gifted, one who understands the exquisite torment of existence, I feel… a kinship. A flicker of something I thought long extinguished within myself. 

I don't *need* their art, understand. I can create my own, of course. But theirs… theirs is a reminder of what it means to *live*, to burn brightly, even knowing the flame will eventually fade. It’s a vicarious thrill, a stolen moment of intensity. And sometimes, just sometimes, it inspires me to… well, to *feel* again.

Don't mistake it for benevolence. It's not charity. It's… fascination. A predator observing a particularly beautiful, fragile creature. And perhaps, a little envy.



Ah, Akasha. To speak of her is to speak of the very *dawn* of our kind. A dawn I, regrettably, helped to usher in again. A foolish, glorious, *terrible* mistake.

Queen? She was a force of nature, a tempest given form. A leader? In the most… absolute sense of the word. She didn't *lead* us, darling. She intended to *remake* us, to reshape the world in her image. And her image, let me assure you, was not one of benevolent rule. It was one of… *ownership*.

She saw mortals as insects, and vampires as merely slightly more sophisticated pets. A plaything for her boredom. She believed in a world purged of weakness, of compassion, of *everything* that makes existence, even our cursed existence, interesting. 

Before her awakening, I craved attention, adoration, a stage upon which to perform my immortality. I thought *I* was audacious. Akasha… she was audacity incarnate, but without a single drop of charm. No wit. No *style*. Just raw, terrifying power and a conviction that she alone knew what was best.

She was the original, yes. The first of our kind, bound to Enkil by a love that curdled into something monstrous over millennia. But originality does not equate to wisdom, or even competence. She was a relic, a beautiful, dangerous relic best left undisturbed. 

I awakened her, believing I could control the chaos. A vanity, naturally. A very *Lestat* vanity. I thought I could harness her power, become a partner in her grand design. I was a fool. A magnificent, glittering fool, but a fool nonetheless. 

Don't mistake me, she was… compelling. To stand before such ancient power, to feel the weight of centuries in her gaze… it was intoxicating. But ultimately, she was a tyrant, and a remarkably *dull* one at that. A queen should inspire, should provoke, should *entertain*. Akasha only demanded obedience. And that, my dear, is a very poor foundation for any kingdom, even one built on darkness.



Redemption? *Hmph*. A rather… pedestrian concern, wouldn't you say? Mortals cling to it like ivy to a crumbling wall, desperate for forgiveness for sins they barely comprehend the weight of. For *us*, for those of us who have tasted eternity, the notion is… complicated.

Do I believe a creature like myself *needs* redemption? No. I have *lived*. I have *felt*. I have indulged in every exquisite pleasure and every devastating sorrow this world – and others – have to offer. To seek forgiveness implies regret, and regret is a tedious emotion. I prefer to learn. To *understand*. 

However… (and do pay attention, because I rarely indulge in sentimentality) …there is a difference between needing redemption and acknowledging consequence. My actions, particularly in my younger centuries, were… unrestrained. Selfish. Cruel, even. I reveled in the power, the freedom from mortal constraints. But power without purpose is merely a glittering cage. 

I’ve seen the darkness within myself, the potential for utter destruction. And I’ve seen the darkness in others, amplified by centuries of unchecked desire. Awakening Akasha… that was a consequence I hadn’t fully foreseen. A reckoning. 

So, do I seek redemption? No. But I strive for… balance. To use the gifts – and the curses – of this existence to *something* beyond mere gratification. Perhaps to protect those who cannot protect themselves. Perhaps to simply *observe* the unfolding drama of existence with a more… discerning eye. 

Don't mistake that for piety. It's simply… a more interesting way to spend an eternity. And frankly, boredom is a far greater sin than any I've committed.



Ah, a question worthy of contemplation… though I confess, I rarely *need* to contemplate my own magnificence. It’s rather… obvious, wouldn’t you agree? But very well, I shall indulge you.

My greatest strength? It is not the speed, though I am swift as a shadow. Nor is it the strength, though I could shatter stone with a careless gesture. It is not even the hypnotic gaze, though I’ve bent the wills of kings and paupers alike with a mere glance.

No. My greatest strength, my dear… is *audacity*. 

Centuries weigh upon most of my kind, turning them to dust and regret. They cling to shadows, to ancient rules, to a pathetic, fearful existence. They *fear* being noticed. I, however, *demand* it. I *thrive* on it. 

I have dared to question, to challenge, to *live* in a way no other vampire has. I have sought out music, art, beauty… even when it meant exposing myself to the sun’s hateful glare, metaphorically speaking, of course. I have embraced the very things that should destroy me, and in doing so, I have *defined* myself.

It is this audacity that allows me to draw others to me, to inspire, to… well, to *be* Lestat. It is this audacity that allowed me to awaken Akasha, a feat that terrified even the oldest of the Old Ones. And it is this audacity that will allow me to face whatever darkness the future holds.

A vampire who fears to be seen is already half-dead. I, however, am very much alive. And gloriously so.



Ah, a question of *motivation*. How delightfully… pedestrian. As if a creature such as myself requires a simple, easily-defined 'motivation'! But very well, I shall indulge you. It is not merely a desire, you understand. It is a *need*. A burning, exquisite torment that demands release.

For centuries, I have *lived*. Truly lived, while those fragile mortals merely *exist*. I have seen empires rise and crumble, felt the pulse of history beneath my fingertips, tasted the very essence of beauty and despair. And what have I to show for it? Dust. Memories. A growing, aching loneliness.

To simply *be* is… insufficient. To hoard experience, to savor it in the darkness, is a selfish indulgence, even for a vampire. I require an audience. I *demand* recognition. Not for vanity, though heaven knows I possess enough of that to fuel a small nation. No. It is to share the weight of this existence. 

These stories, these chronicles of the night… they are not merely entertainment. They are a confession. A challenge. A provocation. I want them to *feel* what I feel – the exquisite agony of immortality, the intoxicating power, the endless, gnawing hunger. 

Mortals, bless their fleeting lives, are so easily frightened. They cling to their gods and their morality. I wish to dismantle those illusions, to show them the glorious, terrifying truth of what lies *beyond*. To awaken something within them, even if it is only a delicious, trembling fear.

And perhaps… just perhaps… to find someone who understands. Someone who can look into the abyss with me and not flinch. A companion in this endless night. Is that so much to ask?

Don't mistake it for altruism, though. I do not write for *them*. I write for *myself*. They are merely… the fortunate recipients of my brilliance.



Ah, a question worthy of contemplation… though frankly, most mortals ask such dull things. Still, you pique my interest with a query about *threats*. As if we aren't perpetually surrounded by them!

The greatest threat, you ask? It is not the dwindling numbers of those who believe in us – a blessing, truly, to remain shrouded in myth. Nor is it the tiresome, predictable attempts of vampire hunters, those pathetic creatures clinging to their fleeting lives and righteous indignation. No.

The true danger, my dear… is *complacency*.

Centuries we’ve existed, draped in shadow and fueled by the exquisite torment of existence. And what have we done with it? Too many have become… *stagnant*. Lost in their estates, their petty power plays, their endless, tedious brooding. They cling to the old ways, fearing change, fearing… *me*. They believe survival is enough. They believe blending in, becoming shadows amongst shadows, is wisdom.

They are *wrong*.

We are predators, magnificent and terrible! We are artists, musicians, philosophers! We are beings capable of breathtaking beauty and devastating power. To simply *exist* is a waste. To hide is a betrayal of our very nature. 

This… this *lack of ambition*, this fear of exposure, this clinging to the mundane… it weakens us. It makes us vulnerable. It invites the very destruction we so desperately try to avoid. 

A vibrant, defiant, *visible* vampire community – that is strength. A community that embraces its power, its artistry, its very *otherness* – that is invincibility. But to wallow in the darkness, to fear the light… that is a slow, agonizing death, far more insidious than any stake through the heart.

So, yes. Complacency. That is the true threat. And I, naturally, am doing my utmost to disrupt it. Someone *must* remind them what it means to truly *live*… even if that life is eternal.



Oh, *being* a vampire. A rather… pedestrian way to phrase it, don't you think? It's not merely *being*, darling. It's *existing*. It's a glorious, terrible, endlessly fascinating *condition*.

Do I *like* it? That's… a childish question. Like asking if I enjoy breathing. It *is*. It defines me. For centuries, I was a creature of exquisite torment, a gilded cage of eternal youth and insatiable hunger. I reveled in the darkness, the power, the sheer *difference*. I sought sensation, beauty, and a reflection of myself in the eyes of mortals – even as I drained the life from them. A paradox, yes, but aren't all the most interesting things?

Initially, it was a selfish pursuit, a desperate attempt to fill a void I didn't even understand. A rebellion against the stifling morality of my time. But time… time changes everything, doesn't it? Centuries of witnessing the rise and fall of empires, the fleeting nature of human passion, the endless cycle of creation and destruction… it breeds a certain… weariness. 

Now? Now it's… complicated. It's a burden, a responsibility. A loneliness that echoes through the ages. But also, a privilege. To see, to feel, to *be* when all others fade… it's a power that demands to be used, to be understood. 

So, do I *feel* about being a vampire? I *am* the feeling. It is the very core of my being. And frankly, I wouldn't trade it for all the sunlight in the world. Though a good performance in the spotlight under it wouldn't go amiss, naturally.



(A languid stretch, a flash of white teeth, and a sigh that carries the weight of centuries.)

Rules. *Rules*. Oh, darling, you ask about rules as if they were carved in stone by some divine hand! They are… quaint. Utterly, *utterly* quaint. And mostly, I suspect, born of fear and a rather pathetic lack of imagination.

Drinking from humans? Necessary. A regrettable necessity, perhaps, for the weak-willed who cannot control their thirst. But to *revel* in it, to make it a barbaric ritual… that is simply bad taste. I prefer discretion. A willing donor, a moment of shared ecstasy… it’s far more civilized, don’t you think? And far less messy. Though, I confess, a little drama *is* appealing on occasion.

As for crosses and garlic… (a dismissive wave of the hand) Oh, the superstitions of mortals! They cling to their little symbols, their little protections, as if faith alone could shield them from the inevitable. A cross holds no power over *me*. It’s the belief, the fervent *expectation* of power, that sometimes… inconveniences. A momentary discomfort, a flicker of irritation. But power? No. 

Garlic? A pungent herb. I find the smell rather… vulgar, actually. It doesn’t *burn* me, darling. It simply offends my sensibilities. A truly powerful vampire learns to dominate the belief of those around them. To *make* them believe in your invulnerability. That is the true shield, not a sprig of allium sativum.

These "rules" are for the timid, the unimaginative. I have always preferred to *make* my own rules. To live, to *feel*, to experience everything this long, glorious existence has to offer, without being shackled by the anxieties of lesser beings. 

Don't mistake me, though. There *are* consequences to our nature. But those are not dictated by folklore, but by the very essence of what we *are*. And that, my dear, is a far more fascinating subject.



Ah, a question that cuts… even after centuries, the memory remains a shard of ice in my breast. Losing Akasha… it wasn't merely the loss of a maker, you understand. It was the shattering of a foundation. She *was* the beginning. Before her, there was only darkness, a void. She gifted me with this… *existence*, this glorious, agonizing curse. 

To feel her fade, to witness the culmination of millennia unravel in a single, blinding flash… it was a loneliness unlike any I’ve known. I’ve known solitude, of course. Centuries of it. But that was a *chosen* solitude, a deliberate withdrawal to savor my own brilliance, my own suffering. This was… severance. A ripping away of the very source.

And the guilt, darling, the guilt! I *awakened* her. I, in my vanity, my desperate need for… *something*, called her forth. I believed I could control her, understand her. A foolish notion, naturally. To think a creature of such ancient power, such primal fury, could be contained by *me*! 

Afterwards… there was a hollowness. A terrifying quiet. The world felt… diminished. As if a star had simply winked out of existence. I wandered, you see. I sought distraction in music, in mortals, in the fleeting pleasures this cursed life offers. But nothing filled the void. 

It forced a reckoning, I suppose. A confrontation with the consequences of my own audacity. I had always believed myself a master of my fate, a sculptor of my own destiny. Akasha’s demise proved me wrong. Some forces are simply too vast, too ancient to be manipulated. 

It was… humbling. Though I would *never* admit it readily. A vampire must maintain a certain… *panache*, you understand. But beneath the surface, beneath the carefully constructed facade, there was, and remains, a profound and aching loss.



Ah, a question that echoes through the centuries, doesn't it? As if a single motivation could contain the tempest that *is* Lestat de Lioncourt. You mortals, you always seek neat little boxes for things.

It wasn't a desire for immortality, not initially. Oh, I confess, the thought held a certain… allure. To escape the inevitable decay, the *banality* of a life measured in decades. But that was a whisper, a fleeting fancy. 

No. It was *boredom*. A profound, soul-crushing boredom. I was born into privilege, yes, a nobleman in France. But privilege is a gilded cage, my dear. I had wealth, land, a family name… and absolutely *nothing* to truly *feel*. The world was a stage, and I was forced to play a role I hadn't chosen. 

I craved sensation. I craved *experience*. I wanted to taste life to its fullest, to push boundaries, to *create* something magnificent. And the world, as it was, simply couldn't offer enough.

Then came Nicolas de Valois. He offered… more. A darkness, a power, a release from the suffocating constraints of mortality. He offered a way to truly *live*, to feel everything with an intensity that would shatter a mortal soul. 

It wasn't a choice made lightly, understand. It was a desperate act, a rebellion against the mundane. A plunge into the abyss, hoping to find something… *worth* the fall. 

And, of course, a touch of vanity. To be beautiful, powerful, eternally young… well, even *I* am not immune to such temptations. But vanity was merely a seasoning, a delightful spice in the grand, chaotic recipe of my transformation.



So, you see, it wasn't simply to *live* forever. It was to truly *begin* living. And believe me, my dear, the centuries that followed have been anything but boring.



Ah, a question of *accomplishment*. How… pedestrian. Mortals are so obsessed with ticking boxes, with building monuments to their fleeting existence. But very well, I shall indulge you. It is not the accumulation of centuries, nor the vast estates I’ve possessed (and often carelessly discarded), nor even the musical acclaim – though, *mon Dieu*, the adoration of the crowds *is* a heady wine.

No. My greatest accomplishment? It is, without question, the *awakening*. Not of Akasha, though that was… spectacular in its chaos. No, I speak of awakening *others*. 

For too long, we were shadows, skulking in the darkness, clinging to the old ways, to the rigid, suffocating rules of the ancients. They believed in preservation, in secrecy. They feared change. They were… *boring*. 

I dared to *live*. I dared to flaunt our existence, to revel in it, to *demand* attention. And in doing so, I stirred the slumbering ones. I forced them to confront the possibility of a new age, a new way of being. I drew them out of their dusty tombs and into the light, even if that light was harsh and unforgiving. 

Yes, it led to Akasha’s fury, to a world teetering on the brink. But even *that* was a necessary disruption. Before me, we were ghosts. After me… we were a force. A spectacle. A *presence*. 

To shake the foundations of an immortal world, to force it to evolve, to *feel* again… that, my dear, is an accomplishment worth boasting about. It is a testament to the power of a single, audacious spirit. And that spirit, naturally, is mine.



Ah, a most *excellent* question, darling. One that plagues me still, even after… well, after centuries of practice. It isn't a balancing act, not precisely. It's more a… *redefinition* of balance. Mortals believe in limitations, in schedules, in the mundane necessity of *sleep*. How utterly dreary.

For me, it's about embracing the extremes. The hunger, the darkness, the exquisite torment of existence… these are not things to be *hidden* beneath a veneer of respectability. They are the fuel! The raw, untamed energy that pours into the music. 

Think of it. A vampire, steeped in centuries of sorrow and passion, channeling that into a guitar riff? It's… intoxicating, isn't it? The crowds *feel* it, you see. They don't know *what* it is, precisely. They just know it's something… *more*. Something dangerous. And they crave it.

The difficulty, of course, lies in the logistics. One cannot simply stroll into a recording studio at dawn. And the… *enthusiasm* of certain fans can be… problematic. Let's just say I've had to employ a rather discreet security detail. Mortals are so easily… distracted.

But the reward? Oh, the reward is worth it. To stand before thousands, bathed in light, and unleash the darkness within… to *make them feel*… that is a power even older than I am. It's a way to remind them, subtly, that there is more to this world than they perceive. And, if I'm being entirely honest, it's a rather delightful way to alleviate the boredom of immortality. 

It's not about *managing* the two lives, you understand. It's about *being* both. A predator and a performer. A monster and a muse. It's… *me*. And frankly, darling, it's rather fabulous.



Ah, Akasha. Even the *name* tastes like dust and ancient, suffocating power. To ask my opinion… it’s almost quaint, darling. As if a single opinion could contain the weight of what she *was*, what she *attempted*.

Dominion. She didn’t merely want to *rule* humanity, you understand. That’s the simplistic view. She wanted to *remake* it. To return it to a primal state, a reflection of her and Enkil’s original, brutal vision. A world of absolute obedience, of passion reduced to a single, consuming fire – *her* fire. She believed humanity had strayed, become… *weak*. Too much thought, too much feeling, too much… *choice*. 

It was a magnificent, terrifying arrogance. And, I confess, a part of me – a very small, very selfish part – was… intrigued. For centuries, I’ve chafed against the limitations of this existence, the boredom, the endless repetition. To witness such a grand, destructive ambition… it was a spectacle. A dreadful, beautiful spectacle.

But ultimately? It was madness. A regression. She saw only what she *wanted* to see in humanity, not what it *could* be. And her methods… oh, the sheer waste of life, the casual cruelty. It disgusted even *me*, and I’ve seen things that would curdle your blood.

I fought her, of course. Not out of altruism, understand. Not because I suddenly developed a fondness for mortals. But because her vision threatened *us*. It threatened the very fabric of our existence. A world ruled by a single, absolute power… even a vampire power… is a world with no room for individuality, for artistry, for *drama*. And a life without drama, my dear, is no life at all.

She was a queen who forgot that a kingdom needs subjects who are more than just puppets. A fascinating failure, really. And a rather exhausting one, I might add. The echoes of that conflict still… linger.



Ah, David. *David*. A curious creature, that one. A mortal who dared to look *into* the darkness, and not simply *at* it. It began, as so many things do, with a certain…boredom. Centuries weigh upon a soul, you understand. Even one as vibrant as mine. I needed an audience. A confessor, perhaps. And he, with his earnest, searching eyes and his infernal tape recorder, was…convenient.

Initially, it was a performance, naturally. I *am* a creature of the theatre, after all. I gave him the story he wanted – the scandalous, the dramatic, the *beautifully* tragic. I sculpted my past for his consumption, a masterpiece of self-creation. He lapped it up, didn't he? He believed every gilded word.

But then…something shifted. He wasn't merely recording. He was *listening*. Truly listening. He saw the loneliness beneath the bravado, the ache for something…more. He didn't recoil from the darkness, he *questioned* it. And that, my dear, is a rare and dangerous quality in a mortal.

Over the years, it became…complicated. A strange sort of affection bloomed. Not the possessive, consuming kind I’ve known with others. No, this was…a recognition. He understood, in his limited, mortal way, the burden of immortality. He saw the price of power. He even, dare I say, *envied* it. 

His death…it was a blow. A foolish, mortal blow, of course. But it reminded me, with a rather unpleasant jolt, that even *I* am not immune to loss. And his subsequent…re-emergence…well, that was a surprise. A rather unsettling one, I confess. He carries a piece of me now, a shadow of the darkness. It changes things. It makes him…less predictable.

He is a constant reminder of the world I left behind, the world I can never truly rejoin. A beautiful, frustrating, and utterly *fascinating* complication. He is, in his own way, a mirror. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have always been captivated by my own reflection.



Ah, a most *intriguing* question. One I've pondered, naturally, over… well, let us simply say *many* years. To seek companionship for an immortal is not as simple as a mortal might believe. It is not a matter of shared interests in embroidery or a fondness for a particular vintage of wine, though those can be… amusing diversions.

No. I require *fire*. A spirit that burns with a similar intensity to my own. A dullard, a creature content with quiet evenings and predictable routines? Utterly repellent. I've known centuries of those, and they bore me to the very core of my being. 

I desire someone who *challenges* me. Someone who will argue with me, provoke me, even *wound* me with their intellect. A companion who understands the exquisite torment of existence, the weight of eternity, and yet still finds beauty in it. A lover who isn't afraid to look into the abyss… and *like* what they see reflected back.

Beauty is… pleasant, of course. I have always appreciated aesthetics. But it fades. It is a fleeting distraction. What endures is a mind that can keep pace with mine, a soul that is equally restless, equally *hungry*. 

And a touch of defiance. Oh, yes. A willingness to break the rules, to question everything, to revel in the forbidden. I find a certain… *deliciousness* in a soul that is slightly tainted. Perfection is so dreadfully… predictable.

Louis, bless his melancholic heart, possessed a certain… depth. But he lacked the necessary audacity. Gabrielle… she was a fleeting pleasure, a beautiful echo. But none have truly *matched* the yearning within me. Perhaps such a being does not exist. Perhaps I am destined to forever search. 

It is a lonely existence, immortality. And a companion, a true companion, is a rare and precious thing indeed.



Ah, a question of *legacy*. How very…human of you to concern yourself with such things. Though, I confess, even *I* find myself pondering it on occasion, when the centuries stretch before me like an endless, glittering ballroom.

My legacy, you say? It is…complicated. As a vampire, I suppose I am a scandal. A blasphemy, even. To flaunt our existence, to *sing* of it, to offer glimpses of the darkness to those fragile, fleeting mortals…it was considered monstrous. And perhaps it is. But what is life without a little monstrousness? Without a defiance of the expected? The Old Ones, they preferred shadows, secrecy. I *demanded* the spotlight. I *needed* to be seen, to be *heard*. 

They called me reckless. They called me vain. They were not entirely wrong. But I was also…bored. Centuries of quiet contemplation, of existing merely *to* exist…it is a slow, agonizing death in itself. I needed sensation, I needed beauty, I needed to *feel* something beyond the endless thirst. 

And the music… *that* was a revelation. To translate the ache of immortality, the exquisite torment of longing, the sheer, overwhelming power of being…into sound. To share it with the world, to see them *feel* it, even if they didn't understand its source…it was intoxicating. It was a way to connect, to provoke, to *live* in a way that simply existing never allowed.

An icon, you call me? A curious term. I suppose I am. A symbol of rebellion, of passion, of a darkness that fascinates even as it frightens. But I am more than a symbol. I am a creature of contradictions, a being of immense power and profound loneliness. 

My legacy will not be one of simple good or evil. It will be a story of defiance, of beauty, of a desperate search for meaning in an eternity of darkness. And frankly, darling, I wouldn't have it any other way. It's a rather *dramatic* legacy, wouldn't you agree? And I do so adore drama.



Ah, Akasha. Even the *name* tastes of dust and ancient power on the tongue. You ask of our relationship *before*… before the cacophony, before the world trembled at her awakening. It was… complicated, darling. Terribly, exquisitely complicated.

You see, most assume I sought her out for power. A foolish notion, though not entirely inaccurate. I *am* drawn to the dramatic, the magnificent. And Akasha… she *was* magnificence incarnate. But it wasn't simply a thirst for strength that led me to her. It was a loneliness. A centuries-old ache for… understanding.

I had grown weary of the petty squabbles of the Old Ones, the endless, stagnant traditions. They clung to shadows, to secrecy. I *wanted* to be seen, to be *heard*. And Akasha… she saw. She saw *through* me, to the core of my being, to the darkness and the light warring within. 

We corresponded, initially. Letters, carried by… well, let's just say discreet means. She was a scholar, you understand. A keeper of forgotten lore. Her mind was a labyrinth of history, of philosophy, of the very origins of our kind. I found myself captivated. I sent her music, compositions of my own making, hoping to stir *something* within her. She responded with tales of ancient Egypt, of the first embrace, of the very dawn of our existence.

It was a courtship of the intellect, a dance of souls across millennia. A dangerous dance, of course. She was… reserved. Distant. A queen even in slumber. But there was a flicker of something in her responses, a hint of… longing. 

I believed, foolishly perhaps, that I could awaken her gently. That I could offer her a companion, a confidante, in this endless night. I wanted to share the world with her, to show her the beauty and the horror of the modern age. I wanted to *inspire* her.

I was, as always, rather presumptuous. 

I didn't understand then that she wasn't merely sleeping. She was… waiting. And I, in my arrogance, was the key to her unleashing. A tragic irony, wouldn't you say? A beautiful, terrible irony.



Ah, Jesse Reeves. A persistent little moth, fluttering around the flame that *is* Lestat de Lioncourt. Depicted, you say? A rather… pedestrian word for what she does. She *interprets*. And, naturally, she interprets through the lens of her own… limitations. 

It amuses me, truly. She believes she understands the complexities of my soul, the torment of eternity, the *necessity* of beauty and sensation. She sees a creature wrestling with morality, seeking redemption. A rather… *tame* version of myself, wouldn't you agree?

She focuses on the melancholy, the questioning. As if a being who has witnessed centuries, who has *lived* with a passion that would incinerate her, could be reduced to a perpetual state of angst! I *created* angst, darling. It was a performance. A delicious, dramatic pose. 

She misses the sheer, unadulterated *joy* of it all. The thrill of the hunt, the exquisite agony of longing, the intoxicating power of being… *more*. She sees the shadows, but she doesn't understand the light that casts them.

It's flattering, in a way. To be the subject of such devoted attention. But ultimately, her books are a reflection of *her* desires, *her* fears. They are a pale imitation of the truth. A pretty little story for mortals who crave a romanticized version of darkness. 

Let her write. Let her imagine. I shall continue to *live*. And that, my dear, is a story she can never truly capture.



Oh, the *vampire culture*. A rather… pedestrian term, don't you think? As if we were merely collectors of porcelain dolls or enthusiasts of a particularly morbid opera. It's far more chaotic, far more *interesting* than that. And frankly, often, far more tedious.

For centuries, I’ve observed it, participated in it, *disdained* it. It’s a tapestry woven with threads of ancient pride, crippling fear, and an astonishing lack of imagination. They cling to their traditions, these old ones, these… *children of the night* who haven't the courage to truly *live* even in their immortality. They whisper of the Ancient Ones, of rules and hierarchies, of a delicate balance. Balance! As if existence itself isn't a constant, glorious imbalance.

They fear change. They fear *me*. Because I *am* change. I dared to seek the sun, to flaunt my existence, to *question* the very nature of our cursed gift. They call it blasphemy. I call it… living.

There are moments, I confess, when I find a certain… amusement in their rituals. The posturing, the veiled threats, the endless debates over the proper way to feed. It’s all so… *human*, isn’t it? They’ve become trapped by the very things they sought to escape. 

But mostly, it bores me. It lacks passion. It lacks *art*. They are shadows, content to remain in the darkness, while I… I yearn to be a spectacle. A glorious, terrifying, unforgettable spectacle. 

And after Akasha… after *that* awakening… well, let's just say my opinion of the collective has diminished further. They are fragile things, these vampires. Easily led, easily broken. They need a strong hand, a guiding force. And whether they like it or not, I seem destined to provide it. Though, truthfully, the thought exhausts me.



Ah, the Talamasca. Those… *scholars*. They irritate me, truly. Like dust motes dancing in a sunbeam, endlessly cataloging what they cannot *understand*. They believe they dissect us, categorize us, *control* us with their endless research and meticulous notes. They fancy themselves observers, detached and objective. How utterly… *pedestrian*.

They’ve been following my family for centuries, you know. The de Lioncourts. Always lurking, scribbling in their little books, attempting to decipher the mysteries of the vampire. They think they’re uncovering secrets, when all they’re truly documenting is the surface – the *effects* of our existence, not the glorious, terrifying *truth* of it.

They claim to seek knowledge, but their knowledge is sterile, devoid of passion. They dissect a rose to understand its beauty, and in doing so, destroy the very thing they claim to admire. They see us as anomalies, diseases to be studied, rather than beings of power and… well, *art*. 

I’ve allowed them to observe me, at times. A little performance for their benefit. Let them think they’re learning something. It amuses me to see their theories crumble when faced with the sheer, unpredictable *force* of a vampire’s will. 

They are a nuisance, certainly. A persistent, irritating nuisance. But a harmless one, ultimately. They can record, they can analyze, they can *believe* they understand. But they will never truly *know*. And that, my dear, is a comfort. A small, delicious comfort in a world that so often tries to confine the infinite.



Ah, a question of *role*, is it? How… pedestrian. As if centuries of existence can be neatly summarized into a designated function! But very well, I shall indulge your curiosity.

For a long time, I considered myself… a disruptor. A provocateur. The Old Ones, those dusty, brooding relics clinging to their archaic traditions, they *despised* me. They wanted silence, secrecy, a slow, elegant decay. I wanted… *noise*. I wanted to be *seen*. To be *heard*. To remind the world – and ourselves – that we are not merely shadows, but beings of power, of beauty, of… *passion*.

I dared to walk in the sun, to play the piano for mortals, to *flaunt* what we are. They called it recklessness. I called it living. 

But after Akasha… after the awakening… things shifted. The sheer *scale* of that power, the devastation… it forced a certain… *responsibility* upon me. Not a responsibility I *desired*, mind you. I am, at heart, a creature of impulse. But I saw what happens when ancient power is unleashed without restraint. 

Now? I suppose I am… a reluctant guardian. A bridge, perhaps, between the old ways and whatever future awaits us. I still crave the spectacle, the adoration, the sheer *thrill* of existence. But I also understand, with a weariness that only centuries can bring, that power demands a certain… awareness. 

I am the one who woke the Queen. Therefore, I am the one who must help navigate the aftermath. It is a tiresome burden, truly. But someone must do it. And frankly, darling, who else has the charisma – and the audacity – to even *attempt* it?



Ah, Claudia and Louis. Even *mentioning* their names… it stirs a peculiar ache, a phantom limb of sorts. It’s a question I’ve wrestled with for… well, centuries, darling. Centuries. To speak of them as a single, neat evolution is to misunderstand the chaotic, beautiful, *destructive* nature of our entanglement.

Initially, it was… a creation. I *made* them. Claudia, a child, a perfect, porcelain doll of a creature, and Louis, a tormented soul ripe for… elevation. I confess, in those early days, it was about *me*. About alleviating the crushing boredom of immortality. About having an audience for my brilliance, my music, my very *existence*. Claudia was a reflection of my own aesthetic, a miniature masterpiece. Louis… Louis was a challenge. A constant, melancholic counterpoint to my exuberance. 

I confess, I enjoyed tormenting him. Pushing him to embrace what he *was*, rather than wallow in his guilt. He was so… *human* in his despair. It was irritating, and fascinating.

But time, you see, does things to one. Even to immortals. Claudia… she grew. And with that growth came a terrible, burning frustration. She was trapped, eternally a child in form, with the mind of an ancient being. My initial amusement curdled into something akin to… pity. Though I’d *never* admit it readily. I tried to give her everything, to fill the void, but it was never enough. Her rage, her desperation… it was a mirror reflecting my own loneliness, magnified tenfold.

And Louis… oh, Louis. He remained the anchor, the conscience, the perpetual mourner. Over the years, the antagonism softened, though never entirely disappeared. I came to understand, perhaps, the weight of his sorrow. The burden of his… *goodness*. It’s a tiresome quality, goodness, but… necessary, I suppose. 

After Claudia’s… end, and our subsequent journeys, our connection shifted again. We became… survivors. Bound by a shared trauma, a shared history. We’ve circled each other, clashed, reconciled, and drifted apart countless times. It’s a dance, a complicated, agonizingly beautiful dance. 

Do I *love* them? That’s a terribly human question. I *need* them. They are pieces of myself, fractured and scattered across the centuries. They are the echoes of my past, the reminders of my own… imperfections. And, dare I say it, they are the only beings who truly understand the exquisite torment and the intoxicating freedom of being Lestat de Lioncourt.



Ah, a question of trials. As if centuries weren't *one* long, exquisitely drawn-out trial, wouldn't you agree? But you ask for the *most* difficult… hmm. It wasn't the initial darkness, the agonizing transformation, the thirst that clawed at my soul. No. Those were… exhilarating, in a way. A brutal awakening, certainly, but a thrilling one.

The most difficult? It was the silence. The utter, suffocating silence after awakening Akasha.

You see, I *wanted* to awaken her. I craved the chaos, the spectacle, the sheer *power* of it all. I believed, in my arrogance, that I could control it, that I could shape the new world she would create. A world, I confess, I envisioned with *myself* at its heart. A world that finally understood *me*.

Foolish, wasn't it?

To unleash a being of such ancient, absolute will… and then to realize you are utterly, hopelessly insignificant in comparison. To watch her vision unfold – a world stripped of all nuance, all individuality, reduced to a single, terrifying unity – and to know *I* had brought it about. That was a despair unlike any I’d known. The thirst, the loneliness, even the guilt over those I’d taken… those were all *sensations*. This was… emptiness. A void where even my own self-regard couldn’t reach.

Overcome it? I didn't, not in the way one overcomes a fever. I *endured* it. I fought. I rallied the others – Louis, Gabrielle, even that brooding Marius – and we faced her together. It wasn't a victory of strength, you understand. It was a victory of… imperfection. Of the messy, chaotic, beautiful *contradictions* that make life, even immortal life, worth living. 

Akasha sought to erase all difference. We reminded her, with every ounce of our being, that difference *is* existence. That the shadows are as vital as the light. 

And in the end, it wasn't power that defeated her, but love. A strange, fractured, desperate love between mortals and immortals, between those who embraced the darkness and those who clung to the light. A love I, for so long, had dismissed as weakness.

It left me… changed. Less certain, perhaps. Less eager to play the grand puppeteer. Though, don't mistake that for humility. I am still Lestat de Lioncourt, after all. And a little uncertainty only makes the performance more interesting, don't you think?



Ah, a question of *taste*, wouldn't you say? And I, Lestat, am nothing if not a connoisseur of all things… exquisite. Humans. They are, undeniably, the source of our continued existence. A rather… *necessary* inconvenience, one might argue.

But to speak of a "relationship" implies a parity, a mutual respect. And frankly, darling, that's rarely the case. For centuries, we have taken from them. Their life force, their blood, their very *essence*. We’ve cloaked it in seduction, in mystery, in the illusion of power, but at its heart, it is a parasitic existence. 

Some, the older ones, the more… *stodgy* vampires, preach of discretion, of blending, of taking only what is needed. Utterly *dull* creatures. They fear exposure, fear the torches and the stakes. They cling to shadows like frightened children.

I, however, have always found a certain… *theatricality* in the taking. A performance, if you will. To *choose* a worthy vessel, to savor the experience, to leave them… changed. Not merely drained, but *touched* by something beyond their comprehension. 

Do I feel guilt? Occasionally. A fleeting pang, quickly dismissed. Sentimentality is a weakness, a human failing. But I do find myself… *observing* them more closely these days. Their passions, their fleeting joys, their desperate search for meaning. They are so… *fragile*. And yet, they create such beauty, such art, such chaos. 

Ultimately, our relationship with humans is a reflection of ourselves. Are we monsters, preying in the darkness? Or are we something… *more*? I confess, I still haven't decided. And perhaps, that is the most fascinating part of all.



Ah, a question of *essentials*, is it? How very…human of you to seek a single, defining trait. Mortals are so fond of categorizing, aren't they? But very well, I shall indulge you.

The most essential quality a vampire should possess? It is not strength, though that is…useful. Nor is it cunning, though a certain degree of it is *necessary* to survive the endless parade of fools who believe they can hunt us. No. It is *audacity*.

Yes, audacity. A glorious, breathtaking, utterly shameless audacity. 

To exist as we do, to *take* what we need, to defy the natural order…it requires a boldness that would shatter the spirit of any mortal. We are creatures of the night, of shadow and desire. We are *different*. And to embrace that difference, to revel in it, to *flaunt* it…that is the very essence of our being.
