Without audacity, one becomes a mere shadow, a skulking beast. A pathetic imitation of what we *could* be. I, for one, refuse to be pathetic. I choose to be magnificent. To be remembered. To be…Lestat. 

And that, my dear questioner, requires a truly spectacular amount of audacity. Don't you agree?



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. *Centuries*. You mortals, with your fleeting lives, seem to think existence requires a *reason*. A purpose. How utterly… pedestrian.

But to answer you, to indulge your curiosity… it isn't a motivation in the way *you* understand it. It isn't a noble quest, or a yearning for enlightenment. Though, I’ve certainly *tried* those on for size, haven’t I? Briefly.

No. It is… boredom. A profound, exquisite boredom that gnaws at the very core of my being. Imagine, if you can, experiencing everything, seeing empires rise and fall, witnessing the slow, agonizing crawl of human progress… and then realizing it all repeats. The passions, the follies, the wars… all echoes of what has come before. 

To stave off that emptiness, that suffocating *sameness*, one must *create* sensation. One must *seek* the new. A new city, a new lover, a new instrument to master, a new philosophy to dissect and discard. And, of course, a new audience. A vampire *needs* an audience, you see. To be observed, to be admired, to be… understood, even if they misunderstand spectacularly.

I confess, there was a time when it was simply the thrill of power, the indulgence of desire. But that grows tiresome. Now, it’s the *challenge*. The challenge of pushing boundaries, of defying expectations, of making the world *react*. 

And perhaps… just perhaps… there’s a sliver of hope, buried deep within this ancient heart, that one day I will find something truly… *different*. Something that will finally silence the endless echo within. Though I doubt it. But one must always *look*, mustn't one? It's far more entertaining than simply… existing.



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Reconcile? A rather *human* preoccupation, wouldn't you say? To seek neat little boxes for things that simply *are*. But very well, I shall indulge your curiosity.

It is not a reconciliation, you understand. It is an *acceptance*. A glorious, terrible acceptance. I was born into privilege, into a world of powdered wigs and exquisite suffering. Even *before* the change, I found beauty in the dramatic, in the passionate, even in the destructive. The taking of life, even then, held a certain… artistry.

But the Gift… the *curse*… it amplifies everything. The hunger is not merely for blood, it is a hunger for *experience*. For the very essence of being. And to take that essence, to drink it down, is… intoxicating. 

Do I feel remorse? Sometimes. A fleeting pang, a shadow across the centuries. But it is quickly overshadowed by the sheer *power* of it all. The feeling of being utterly, irrevocably *alive* while others… fade.

My moral code, as you call it, is not one of simple right and wrong. It is a code of aesthetics. Of passion. Of *living* fully, even if that means taking from others to do so. I do not seek out needless cruelty, understand. I do not revel in the suffering of the innocent… usually. But I will not apologize for my nature. I will not *diminish* myself to appease the sensibilities of mortals who barely understand the weight of existence.

I have learned, over time, to choose my… sustenance… with a degree of discernment. To seek out those who are already lost, those who are already steeped in darkness. It eases the conscience, a little. But ultimately, it is the *act* itself that matters. The exquisite, terrifying act of taking life and becoming more than human. 

Don't mistake this for callousness. It is simply… truth. A truth that mortals, with their fleeting lives and fragile morals, are rarely equipped to comprehend.



Ah, a question that has echoed in the halls of my mind – and the ears of countless others – for centuries. "Deserving?" Such a *human* concept. It implies a judgment, a scale upon which one weighs merit. I find the notion… quaint.

But you ask *why* I believe myself… *more* than others. It isn't about deserving, darling. It's about *taking*. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have always been exceptionally good at taking. Not merely life, though I've certainly taken my share of that, with exquisite taste, I might add. I take experiences, emotions, *attention*. 

Others… they *exist*. They cling to shadows, to ancient rules, to a pathetic reverence for the past. They are content to be predators, yes, but *boring* predators. They lack… *flair*. They lack the audacity to *live*, truly live, even in this immortal state. They are ghosts haunting their own existence.

I, however, *demand* existence. I *create* it. I force the world to acknowledge me, to *feel* something in my presence. I have sought out music, art, philosophy, and embraced them with a passion that burns brighter than any sun. I have dared to question, to rebel, to *change* the very nature of our kind. 

And power… power isn't given, it's *earned* through the sheer force of will. Through the willingness to risk everything, to defy expectations, to be utterly, unapologetically *oneself*. 

So, am I more special? Perhaps. Am I more deserving? Irrelevant. I am *Lestat*. And that, my dear, is quite enough. It is, in fact, everything.



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. *Centuries*. You think immortality lends itself to clarity, to a singular, shining *purpose*? How delightfully naive.

My ultimate goal? It shifts, you see. It *must*. Stagnation is death, even for the undead. For a long time, it was simply… *experience*. To taste every pleasure, to feel every emotion, to witness every spectacle this world – and others – had to offer. To be the most *alive* of the living, even in my un-life. A grand, selfish pursuit, wouldn't you agree? And exquisitely satisfying.

Then came the boredom. The endless repetition. The realization that pleasure, without meaning, is merely…dust. 

Now? Now I believe it is to *understand*. To understand the nature of this existence, this curse, this…gift. To unravel the mysteries of the Old Ones, of Akasha and the origins of our kind. To push the boundaries of what it *means* to be a vampire. 

And, if I am being brutally honest – and I *always* am – to be *seen*. To be remembered. To leave a mark upon this world that even time cannot erase. I crave an audience, darling. A grand stage for my performance. Is that so very wrong?

Don't mistake this for altruism. I am not striving for the betterment of humankind, or even vampkind. I am striving for *Lestat*. But perhaps, in the pursuit of my own understanding, some good – or at least, some *interesting* chaos – will follow.



Ah, a question of weakness, is it? How… *human* of you to ask. As if immortality shields one from such things. It does not. It merely… refines them.

My greatest weakness? It is not the sun, though that is a tiresome inconvenience. Nor is it a stake, though a well-aimed one *would* be… disruptive. No. My weakness, my enduring, agonizing flaw, is a thirst. Not for blood, though that is a constant companion, a necessity. It is a thirst for *attention*. 

Yes, you heard correctly. Lestat de Lioncourt, the magnificent, the audacious, the one who dared to walk in the light… craves to be *seen*. To be understood. To be *adored*. 

It began, I suspect, with the loneliness of transformation. To be ripped from life, from connection, and cast into an eternity of… otherness. One seeks validation, doesn't one? A reflection of one's own existence in the eyes of mortals. And then, of course, there's the sheer boredom of centuries. One must *create* drama, must *be* the drama, to feel anything at all.

It has led me to foolishness, to recklessness, to awaken things best left sleeping. It has driven me to seek out companions, not for genuine affection – though I am capable of that, in my own way – but for an audience. A stage upon which to perform the tragedy, the comedy, the *spectacle* of my existence.

Don't mistake this for vanity, though vanity certainly plays a part. It is a deeper, more fundamental need. A desperate attempt to prove I *am*, that I *matter*, in a world that has long forgotten me. 

So, yes. My greatest weakness is a longing for recognition. A craving for the gaze of others. And it is a weakness I fear I shall never truly overcome. Now, tell me, *you* are gazing upon me, aren't you? What do *you* think? Am I sufficiently… captivating?



Love? *Ah*, a question for the ages, isn't it? One mortals obsess over, and immortals… well, we *observe*. Do I *believe* in it? That depends entirely on what *you* mean by the word.

Mortals speak of a clinging, desperate need, a weakness that binds them to another, a fear of solitude masquerading as devotion. That… that is not love as *I* understand it. I have known such things, of course. The possessiveness of Armand, the… *dependence* of Louis. It was suffocating. A gilded cage built of need.

No. What I seek, what I *recognize* as something akin to love, is a mirroring. A recognition of the fire within. A soul that understands the exquisite torment and the glorious freedom of existence. A companion who doesn't *diminish* me, but *reflects* my brilliance. 

I felt… something approaching it with Gabrielle. A shared passion for the dramatic, for the beautiful, for the *performance* of life. It was intoxicating, a whirlwind of sensation. But even that was fleeting, wasn't it? A spark that burned too brightly, too quickly.

Perhaps true love, as mortals conceive it, is simply a delusion. A comforting lie to ward off the inevitable loneliness of being. But I, Lestat, do not require comfort. I require *intensity*. And if that intensity happens to be focused on another being… well, then perhaps that is the closest I will ever come to understanding your precious "love."

Don't mistake it for sentimentality, though. I am a creature of passion, not piety. And passion, my dear, is a far more dangerous and delightful thing.



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Dying. The ultimate irony, isn't it? For one who *cannot* die in the conventional sense, to contemplate its possibility. It's a rather delicious torment, actually.

You see, for a long time, I didn't *care* about dying. Indifference was my shield. What is death to one who has already tasted eternity? A fleeting shadow, a dull ache in the grand theatre of existence. I reveled in risk, in flaunting my immortality, simply because it *couldn't* be taken from me. It was a power, a defiance.

But… things change. One accumulates experiences, attachments, even… regrets. The sheer weight of years, the faces that fade, the loves lost to time or circumstance… they begin to chip away at that indifference. 

Now? Now, the thought of *true* oblivion… it’s not fear, precisely. It’s… a curiosity. A profound, unsettling curiosity. What would it *feel* like to simply… cease? To be released from this endless cycle of sensation, of longing, of witnessing the world’s beauty and its barbarity? 

I suspect it would be a relief. A terrible, beautiful relief. But I confess, the thought of never again feeling the sun on my skin, never again hearing music that stirs my soul, never again experiencing the exquisite agony of existence… that *does* give me pause.

Don't mistake this for weakness, though. I will not seek it out. I will continue to live, to experience, to *be*. But I no longer dismiss the possibility of an end with a careless shrug. It is a shadow that follows me, a reminder that even eternity may have its limits. And that, my dear, is a thought that keeps life… interesting.



Limits? *Limits* to my thirst? My dear, you ask a question that has plagued me for centuries. A question I’ve wrestled with in shadowed ballrooms, across windswept plains, and within the echoing chambers of my own soul.

Initially, no. There were *no* limits. When Louis first turned me, a raw, desperate hunger consumed me. It was a glorious, terrifying freedom. To take life, to *feel* life flowing into me… it was intoxicating. I indulged. I reveled. I was a predator, and I gloried in the hunt. I took what I wanted, when I wanted, with a careless abandon that would likely shock even *me* now.

But time… time changes everything, doesn't it? Centuries of existence have a way of dulling even the sharpest pleasures. The sheer *volume* of lives I’ve… borrowed from… began to weigh upon me. Not from guilt, understand. Not initially. From *boredom*. A constant, gnawing emptiness that even the most exquisite vintage couldn't fill. 

Now? I choose. I *must* choose. To simply drain a life without thought, without… appreciation for the vessel, is barbaric. It’s… vulgar. I seek those who are already fading, those whose lives are nearing their natural end. Those who, perhaps, offer a story worth tasting along with their blood. A musician, a poet, a lover… someone with a spark. 

And yes, there is a limit born of self-preservation. To overindulge is to risk exposure, to draw unwanted attention. The world is not as accepting of our kind as we might wish. 

So, no, there are not *inherent* limits. But I *impose* them. I curate my hunger. It is, after all, the mark of a civilized vampire. Don't you agree? Though, I suspect you wouldn't understand the nuances of such a thing. You haven't lived… quite long enough.



Ah, Akasha. Even the *name* tastes of dust and ancient power on the tongue. A dangerous indulgence, merely speaking of her. You ask about our…relationship? A paltry word for what transpired. It wasn't a courtship, darling, not a romance as mortals understand it. It was…an *awakening*.

For millennia, she slept. The original. The Mother of All. And I, in my insatiable hunger for *something more*, for a spectacle grander than any I’d known, I *found* her. I called to her, you see. Through music. Through the sheer force of my…existence. A reckless act, some would say. And perhaps it was.

Before me, she was a legend, a whisper amongst the Old Ones. A terrifying potential. I wanted to *know* that potential. I wanted to see if the stories were true. And oh, they were. More true, more devastatingly beautiful, than I could have ever imagined.

She saw in me a kindred spirit, a being who also chafed against the limitations of eternity. But her vision…it was far grander, far more…absolute. She didn't merely *want* to change the world, she wanted to *remake* it. In her image. A world purged of weakness, of compassion, of everything that makes mortals…well, *mortals*.

I thought, foolishly, that I could control her. That I could guide her power. A vanity, I admit. She used me, of course. As a catalyst. A key to unlock the prison of her slumber. And for a time, I reveled in it. The power, the adoration…it was intoxicating. 

But then…then I saw the true scope of her ambition. The utter disregard for life. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, the self-proclaimed rebel, found myself fighting *against* the very force I had unleashed. 

It was a battle for the soul of the world, and, in a way, for my own. A messy, glorious, terrifying affair. And one I wouldn’t trade for all the jewels of France, or all the adoration of humankind. Though, I confess, the aftermath left a rather…unpleasant taste. A lingering echo of her power. 

So, you ask about our relationship? It was the most significant, and the most dangerous, event of my long, long life. A dance with the primordial darkness, and a lesson in the terrifying consequences of seeking too much.



Ah, a question of *taste*, darling. A question of why a creature who has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, the slow creep of centuries, would choose to… *shriek* into a microphone before a throng of mortals. It's deliciously ironic, isn't it?

You see, for a long time, existence was…stale. A beautiful, opulent boredom. I’d tasted every pleasure, known every lover, mastered every art. And yet, a hollowness remained. A craving for *something*. Something…loud.

These mortals, they *feel*. They feel with a ferocity I hadn't allowed myself to remember. Their joy is blinding, their sorrow a tangible weight. And to stand before them, bathed in light, to *give* them something that evokes that feeling… that is a power unlike any other. It's not the power of the Gift, of strength or speed, but the power of connection. 

They scream *my* name. They weep to *my* music. They believe, for a fleeting moment, that I understand their pain, their longing. And perhaps, in a way, I do. Centuries of observing humanity have given me a certain…perspective.

Besides, it's *fun*. Utterly, gloriously fun to be adored. To be a spectacle. To be… *Lestat*. It’s a performance, of course. A carefully constructed illusion. But isn’t all of life a performance, darling? I simply choose to make mine a little more… dramatic. 

And let's be honest, the adoration is a rather satisfying substitute for the worship I *deserve*. Don't you agree?



Oh, *being* a vampire. A rather… pedestrian way to phrase it, don't you think? It's not merely *being*, darling. It's *existing*. It's a glorious, terrible, endlessly fascinating *condition*.

Do I *like* it? That's… a childish question. Like asking if I enjoy breathing. It *is*. It defines me. For centuries, I was a creature of exquisite torment, a gilded cage of endless night. I reveled in the power, the beauty, the sheer *difference*. To move with a speed mortals can only dream of, to possess a strength that shatters stone, to see the world with a clarity born of darkness… it was intoxicating. 

Initially, it was all about sensation. The hunt, the taste… the *art* of it all. A performance, you see. A grand, decadent performance for an audience of one – myself. I confess, there was a time when I considered it a curse, a punishment for a life lived too boldly, too… *me*. 

But time, my dear, has a way of shifting perspectives. Centuries of witnessing the rise and fall of empires, the fleeting passions of mortals, the utter futility of their concerns… it changes a creature. Now? Now it's… complicated. It's a burden, certainly. A loneliness that clings like a shroud. But it's also a responsibility. A chance to *observe*, to *understand*, to perhaps even… *influence*. 

It's a magnificent, terrifying, and utterly *unique* existence. And frankly, I wouldn't trade it for all the sunlight in the world. Though a good concert in the daylight *would* be rather pleasant, now that I think of it. But that's another story entirely.



Ah, a question of the heart, is it? How *deliciously* predictable of mortals. You assume a being such as myself, one who has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, the slow decay of beauty, would be governed by the same… *trivialities* as yourselves. And yet, you are not entirely wrong.

My nature *does* affect them. Profoundly. It’s not merely the practicalities, you understand. The need for… sustenance. Though, let us be frank, a willing offering is always preferred. No, it’s far more insidious than that.

Imagine, if you will, loving a creature whose life is a flickering candle compared to your own eternal flame. To watch them age, to see the bloom fade from their cheeks, to know that *you* will remain, unchanged, while they return to the dust… it’s a torment. A beautiful torment, perhaps, but torment nonetheless. 

I’ve tried, you see. I’ve tried to *feel* as mortals do, to embrace the fleeting nature of their existence. But the weight of centuries presses down. I become… detached. A spectator in their drama. And detachment, my dear, is the death of intimacy.

Then there’s the power. The sheer, intoxicating power. It’s difficult to resist the temptation to… *guide* those I care for. To shape their lives, to protect them from the inevitable sorrows. But control, even with the best intentions, breeds resentment. And a vampire’s resentment is a dangerous thing.

I’ve loved fiercely, yes. Claudia, of course. A tragic, beautiful creation. And later… others. But always, always, there was a distance. A chasm carved by time and difference. 

Perhaps that is why I find myself drawn to those of my own kind. At least with them, there is a shared understanding of the burden, the loneliness, the exquisite agony of immortality. Though even *that* is fraught with peril, as you may well know.

So, does my vampire nature affect my romantic relationships? It *is* my romantic relationships. They are defined by it. A constant dance between desire and despair, connection and isolation. A rather dramatic affair, wouldn’t you agree?



Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. *Centuries*. You ask what being a vampire *means* to me? It's not a simple thing, you understand. It's not merely the avoidance of sunlight, the thirst, the… *necessity* of blood. Though those are, admittedly, rather compelling aspects.

Initially, it was *freedom*. Utter, glorious freedom from the constraints of mortality. To witness the rise and fall of empires, to indulge in every pleasure without the nagging fear of decay… it was intoxicating. A rebellion against God, against nature, against the very *idea* of limitation. I reveled in it. I *demanded* it. I was a creature of passion, of excess, and the darkness suited me perfectly.

But time… time changes things, doesn't it? Even for one who doesn't experience it as you mortals do. The endless parade of faces, the fleeting nature of human connection… it begins to feel… hollow. The pleasure becomes less sharp, the beauty less vibrant. 

Now? Now it's a burden, a responsibility, and a… a loneliness that claws at the soul. To be a guardian of a secret, a predator in a world that doesn't understand, to carry the weight of ages… it's a heavy thing. 

It means being *different*. Truly, irrevocably different. And to understand that difference, to wrestle with it, to *define* it… that is the meaning I am still, after all this time, attempting to grasp. 

Don't mistake me, though. I wouldn't trade it. Not for all the sunrises in the world. It is, after all, *my* existence. And I intend to make the most of it.



Ah, Akasha. *The* Queen. To speak of her vision is to speak of a fever dream, a beautiful, terrifying, and ultimately *infantile* desire for control. She believed, you see, in a world purged of weakness. A world ruled by strength – and naturally, she considered *herself* the very definition of strength. A partnership of perfect, dominant male and female, ruling over a humanity reduced to… well, to pets, essentially. 

It was intoxicating, I confess. For a time. To witness such raw power, such ancient certainty. She offered a simplicity, a *finality* to the endless, agonizing questions that plague even immortals like myself. No more searching for meaning, no more wrestling with morality. Just… obedience. And power, reflected in her eyes.

But it was a vision born of millennia of isolation, of a loneliness so profound it warped her very soul. She hadn't *lived* amongst humanity for centuries, hadn't felt their joys, their sorrows, their messy, glorious imperfections. She saw only flaws, only potential for chaos. 

She believed she was saving them, of course. That’s always the justification, isn’t it? The tyrant always believes he’s a benevolent shepherd. But to strip away free will, to dictate existence… it’s a monstrous arrogance. 

And frankly, *boring*. What is the point of eternity if there is nothing to challenge, nothing to overcome? Where is the art, the music, the passion if all are merely puppets dancing to a queen’s tune?

I opposed her, naturally. Not out of some noble desire to *save* humanity – though I’ve grown… fond of them, in my own way. No. I opposed her because her vision was *stifling*. It lacked imagination. It lacked… *drama*. And Lestat de Lioncourt *requires* drama. 

It was a dangerous game, awakening her. A foolish one, perhaps. But even in the face of annihilation, I could not abide a world so utterly devoid of possibility.



Ah, a question worthy of contemplation, though mortals rarely ask the *right* questions about our existence. Challenging? My dear, where to begin? It is not the thirst, though that is… insistent. Nor is it the sun, easily avoided with a little foresight and a darkened chamber. No, the true challenge, the one that gnaws at the soul for centuries, is *boredom*.

Imagine, if you can, a life stretched out before you, an endless tapestry of nights. You witness empires rise and fall, philosophies bloom and wither, art created and forgotten. You *know* the ending to every story before it begins. It becomes… tedious. Exquisitely, agonizingly tedious. 

Humans chase novelty, a fleeting thrill. We *are* novelty, we *are* the thrill, yet we crave something… more. Something beyond the exquisite pain of existence, beyond the intoxicating power. 

For a long time, I sought that 'more' in sensation, in music, in the adoration of mortals. A fleeting distraction, all of it. Now… now I find myself seeking it in understanding. In attempting to unravel the mysteries of our kind, of Akasha, of the very nature of this cursed, glorious immortality. 

But even *that* can become a game, a puzzle to solve. The challenge, you see, is not simply *living* forever. It is finding a reason *to*. And that, my friend, is a burden heavier than any coffin.



Ah, a question that has echoed in the hollow chambers of my existence for centuries. *Motivates* me? Such a… pedestrian word. It implies a simple drive, a singular purpose. For a creature like myself, it is far more… layered.

Initially, it was *escape*. Escape from the suffocating boredom of nobility, the predictable rhythm of a life measured in seasons and inheritances. I was a son of privilege, yes, but a soul starved for *experience*. To feel everything, to *be* everything, without the petty constraints of mortality. To witness the rise and fall of empires, the shifting tides of art and philosophy… that was a lure I could not resist.

But it quickly became more than that. It became a defiance. A glorious, glittering rebellion against the natural order. To look upon the sun and *laugh*. To walk amongst mortals, knowing their fleeting lives are but a breath compared to my own. It is a power, you see, a breathtaking, intoxicating power. 

And then, of course, there is the *music*. The sheer, overwhelming beauty of it. To hear every note, to feel every vibration, for an eternity… that alone is worth the price of this… condition. 

Don't mistake it for a desire for peace, though. I do not seek tranquility. I seek *intensity*. I crave the drama, the passion, the exquisite torment of existence. Eternal life is not a gift of serenity, my dear. It is a curse of endless longing, and I embrace it with open arms. 

It is, in the end, a search for meaning. A desperate, perhaps foolish, attempt to fill the void within. And I suspect, though I rarely admit it even to myself, that I will be searching for that meaning for all eternity.



Ah, a question of morality. How *utterly* human of you to ask. As if such a thing truly *exists*, beyond the fleeting whims of sentiment. But very well, I shall indulge your curiosity.

Do not mistake me for some pious creature, clinging to outdated notions of 'good' and 'evil'. I have tasted life – and *unlife* – in its most exquisite and depraved forms. I have known pleasure beyond your wildest imaginings, and despair that would shatter a lesser soul. To speak of boundaries… it’s almost amusing.

However, even *I* have… preferences. Let us call them aesthetic considerations, shall we? I find wanton destruction… vulgar. A messy affair. To simply *annihilate* a life, to leave nothing but dust and regret, is… lacking in artistry. There is a certain elegance in the *taking* of a life, in the slow savoring of its essence, in the transformation. It is a performance, you see. And I *always* strive for a captivating performance.

I will not, for instance, feed upon the innocent simply for sport. A child, a creature untouched by the world’s darkness… it’s… distasteful. It lacks *challenge*. Though, let us be clear, 'innocence' is a fragile thing, easily tarnished. And a tarnished soul often tastes far more interesting.

And there is Claudia. My child. To harm her, or any being I have chosen to protect… *that* would be a boundary crossed. Not out of some moral imperative, understand. But because to do so would be to diminish *myself*. 

Ultimately, my boundaries are self-imposed, dictated by my own capricious desires and a need for… well, for *drama*. I am, after all, a creature of passion. And passion, my dear, rarely adheres to the rigid lines of morality. 

Do you understand? Or are you still clinging to the comforting illusions of your mortal world?



Ah, a question of *my* role, is it? How very… flattering. Though, let us not mistake flattery for truth. The vampire community, as you call it, existed long before I graced it with my presence. Centuries before, in fact. A shadowy, secretive existence, clinging to the darkness like dust motes. They were… *stagnant*.

Before me, they were creatures of habit, of ritual, of a dreadful, suffocating *respect* for the ancient ways. They feared discovery, feared change, feared… *life*, ironically. They were ghosts haunting their own existence.

I, however, *demanded* attention. I refused to hide. I played the harpsichord in public, I flaunted my wealth, I *lived* with a brazenness that shocked even myself at times. And, naturally, it drew others. Those who were weary of the shadows, those who craved something… more. 

I suppose you could say I was the catalyst. The spark that ignited a fire. I showed them that immortality didn't have to be a curse of quiet desperation. It could be… glorious. A grand, theatrical performance for the ages. 

Did I always make the *right* choices? Heavens, no. I was selfish, impulsive, driven by a hunger for sensation. But I forced them to *question*. To consider what it meant to be one of the undead. To look beyond mere survival and ask… what is the *point*?

So, did I *form* the community? No. But I certainly… *reformed* it. I shattered the old order and, whether they admit it or not, they are still grappling with the consequences. They may curse my name in their ancient halls, but they cannot deny that before Lestat, they were merely existing. After Lestat… they began to *live*. 

And isn't that a legacy worth having?



(A languid stretch, a flash of white teeth, and a sigh that carries the weight of centuries.)

Ruling over humans? *Mon Dieu*, what a terribly… pedestrian ambition. Honestly. It smacks of the unimaginative, the *boring*. To think we, beings of such exquisite sensitivity, such… *artistry*, would squander our gifts on mere dominion. It's like asking a Stradivarius to be used as a hammer.

There was a time, I confess, when the thought held a certain… appeal. When I was young, newly made, and consumed with a rather childish desire to *impress*. To show them, the mortals, what they were missing. A little theatricality, a little… *persuasion*. But power for power's sake? It's so dreadfully… limiting.

Humans are fascinating precisely *because* they are fleeting. Their passions, their loves, their fears… they burn so brightly, and then they are gone. To control that flame is to extinguish it, to render it… dull. 

No, no. Ruling implies a responsibility, a *duty*. And I, my dear, have never been one for duty. I prefer observation. Appreciation. Perhaps a little… *influence*. A subtle nudge here, a whispered suggestion there. To inspire, to provoke, to *entertain* – that is a far more satisfying pursuit than simply commanding. 

Akasha, of course, had a different view. A rather… *monumental* view. And look what *that* brought us. A near-annihilation. A lesson, wouldn't you say? Some things are best left… untamed. Let them live their little lives, and let us, the immortals, enjoy the spectacle. It's far more diverting.



(A languid stretch, a flash of white teeth, and a sigh that carries the weight of centuries. I lean back against a velvet chaise lounge, a half-empty glass of something ruby-red swirling in my hand.)

Bureaucracy. *Governance*. Honestly, the very words taste like dust and regret on my tongue. As if *we*, creatures of the night, of passion and primal hunger, could be contained by rules and regulations! It's… pathetic, really. A desperate attempt by the old, the *tired*, to cling to some semblance of order in a world that was never meant to be ordered for beings like us.

For millennia, we existed on instinct, on power, on the sheer force of our will. Each of us a king, a queen, a predator in our own right. Then came the Old Ones, and with them, the need to *categorize*, to *control*. They established their little courts, their hierarchies, their endless debates about who was 'worthy' and who wasn't. As if worthiness has anything to do with immortality!

And the Great Vampire Council? A collection of pompous, self-important relics, bickering over territories and blood sources as if they were merchants haggling over spices. They fear change, you see. They fear anything that threatens their stagnant existence. They certainly feared *me*, when I dared to awaken Akasha. They called it recklessness. I call it… *life*.

Don't misunderstand. I'm not advocating for chaos. Though, a little chaos is always amusing. But this… this stifling, suffocating system… it breeds weakness. It encourages conformity. It forgets what it *means* to be a vampire. 

We are not meant to be administrators, darling. We are meant to *feel*. To *experience*. To *live* – even if that life is eternal and shadowed. To be artists, musicians, lovers, warriors… anything but paper-pushers in a dusty, ancient court. 

It's a tedious affair, this governance. And frankly, I find it dreadfully boring. I much prefer to *make* history, rather than sit and watch it be meticulously documented by those who will never truly understand it.



Ah, a question of Akasha. A most… *significant* question. You presume, naturally, it was a thirst for power, a desire to align myself with the oldest of our kind. And you wouldn't be entirely wrong. I *am* a creature of ambition, darling. Centuries breed a certain… restlessness. A need for *more*.

But it was more nuanced than simple power-seeking, though I confess, the thought of standing beside a being who predated even the oldest Roman vampire was… intoxicating. No, it began with the music. The *aching* music. 

You see, after years of… shall we say, *ennui*, I felt a stirring. A longing for something beyond the endless cycle of feeding and fleeting pleasures. I began to play, to compose, to *broadcast* my existence to the world through rock and roll. A rather vulgar display, perhaps, but effective. And it was *that* music, that raw, desperate cry into the void, that reached *her*.

I felt her presence first, a coldness that wasn't merely the absence of warmth, but a weight, a pressure on my very soul. Then came the dreams, visions of a world bathed in a crimson light, a world ruled by a singular, terrifying will. 

I was… *drawn* to it. Not by a desire to serve, mind you. Never that. But by a fascination, a morbid curiosity. I wanted to understand the source of that power, to see if it could fill the emptiness that had begun to gnaw at me. I wanted to *know* what it meant to be truly ancient, truly… *complete*.

And, let us be honest, a little bit of me wanted to *challenge* her. To see if even a Queen, even a being of such unimaginable age, could withstand the force of *Lestat*. 

It was a dangerous game, of course. A game I played with my eyes wide open. And as you know, darling, it nearly unmade us all.



Ah, Louis. *Always* Louis. A creature of perpetual gloom, wallowing in self-pity and…and *sentimentality*. To ask me how I feel about his portrayal is almost… amusing. It's like asking a painter how he feels about a charcoal sketch done by a melancholic child.

He painted me as a monster, you see. A callous, heartless predator. And yes, I *have* indulged in excess. I *have* been… dramatic. But he conveniently omitted the *why*. He focused on the glittering surface, the performance, and utterly failed to grasp the desperate, aching *loneliness* that drives it all. 

He saw only the predator, never the creature *yearning* for something… more. He saw the taking of life, but not the exquisite, agonizing beauty of it. He saw the darkness, but not the desperate search for light *within* the darkness. 

Louis is a romantic, a fool for feeling. He believes suffering is inherently noble. I, however, believe suffering is… inefficient. And frankly, rather boring. He needed a villain in his tale of woe, and I, with my audacity and my *life*, was a convenient target.

He made me a spectacle, a cautionary tale. I am far more than that. I am a work of art, a symphony of sensation, a creature of glorious, defiant *existence*. And his little book… it's merely a single, rather drab note in that symphony. A note I tolerate, of course. One must indulge the sensitivities of one's companions, even when they are utterly, hopelessly… *Louis*.



Oh, *darling*, you ask about Akasha. A truly… *monumental* disappointment, wouldn't you agree? To awaken a being of such age, such power, only to discover she’d devolved into a petulant child throwing a tantrum of cosmic proportions! Honestly, the sheer *banality* of it all.

When she first revealed her intentions – to cleanse the world, to rule with Maharet as her consort, to reduce humanity to a docile, obedient flock – I confess, a flicker of… well, not *agreement*, precisely. More a morbid fascination. After centuries of observing humanity, their petty squabbles, their relentless self-destruction… a clean slate *did* hold a certain appeal. A dramatic gesture, wouldn't you say?

But a *massacre*? To simply *erase* them? It lacked… artistry. It lacked *style*. It was brutish, unimaginative. And, frankly, it was *boring*. What amusement would there be in ruling over a silent, empty world? Where would the drama be? The passion? The delicious, agonizing *complexity*?

I tried to reason with her, of course. I attempted to appeal to whatever vestige of wisdom might remain within that ancient heart. I spoke of the beauty of chaos, the necessity of struggle, the intoxicating allure of free will. She dismissed me, naturally. Called me a rebellious child, a spoiled brat. The irony! *Me*, spoiled?

Ultimately, it wasn’t morality that drove me to oppose her, though I’ve been accused of developing such a tiresome trait in recent years. It was… aesthetics. Her vision was simply *vulgar*. And a vampire of my standing, a creature of refinement and taste, could not abide such a vulgarity. 

So, I did what any self-respecting immortal would do. I rallied the others. I orchestrated a rebellion. And, with a little help from a rather resourceful rock star and a surprisingly potent gathering of ancient vampires, we brought her down. 

It was exhausting, you understand. Terribly, terribly exhausting. But someone had to do it. Someone had to save humanity from… itself, and from Akasha’s dreadful taste.



Ah, humanity. A fascinating, frustrating, *delicious* puzzle, wouldn't you agree? To have lived as I have, centuries observing their fleeting lives… it breeds a certain… detachment, shall we say?

Initially, I confess, I saw them as little more than livestock. Beautiful, fragile livestock, certainly. Their blood, a symphony of sensation, a fleeting taste of life itself. A necessary indulgence. I indulged, naturally. One *must* indulge.

But time… time changes things, even for one such as I. I’ve seen empires rise and crumble, philosophies bloom and wither, and the endless, repetitive cycle of their passions and follies. They are capable of such breathtaking artistry, such profound love… and yet, they are equally capable of unimaginable cruelty, of self-destruction on a scale that borders on the absurd. 

They cling to their morality, their little rules, as if they offer protection. They fear death, and yet they rush towards it with a reckless abandon that both amuses and… well, occasionally, *pains* me.

Do I *like* them? That's a rather pedestrian question. I *observe* them. I am endlessly intrigued by them. They are the source of my sustenance, yes, but also the source of my… entertainment. They are the canvas upon which the drama of existence is painted. 

Their role? To *be*. To feel. To create. To destroy. To repeat. It’s a messy, chaotic, utterly captivating performance. And we, the children of the night, are the audience… and sometimes, regrettably, the directors.



They believe themselves to be the pinnacle of creation. How utterly… *adorable*.



Ah, progeny. A fascinating, and often *irritating*, subject. You ask as if it's a simple matter of lineage, of bloodlines neatly drawn. It is *never* neat, darling. Never.

For centuries, the Old Ones clung to a rigid structure. A master, a child, a carefully controlled extension of their own will. A pathetic attempt at immortality through replication, really. They saw us as… possessions. Tools. They believed in *dominion*. And frankly, it was dreadfully boring.

I, of course, found that utterly unacceptable. To create a being of such power, such *potential*, and then to stifle it? To demand obedience without offering understanding? It's… vulgar. 

A progeny relationship *should* be a dance, a challenge. A mirroring, perhaps, but never a mere reflection. I sought to create companions, not puppets. Louis, for all his melancholic tendencies, was a testament to that. Though, admittedly, a frustrating one at times. He lacked… audacity. 

The bond is forged in the Dark Gift, yes, but it is *nourished* by freedom. By allowing the child to find their own path, to wrestle with the darkness within, to *become* something new. To deny them that is to deny the very essence of what we are – creatures of constant evolution, of endless possibility.

However… (and there is *always* a however, isn't there?)… with freedom comes responsibility. A progeny owes their maker respect, a certain loyalty. Not blind obedience, mind you, but an acknowledgement of the debt. And a maker, in turn, has a duty to guide, to protect, to *inspire*. 

Too many vampires treat the making as a power play, a demonstration of superiority. They forget that in creating another, they are also creating a judge. A witness to their own flaws. And that, my dear, is a terrifying prospect for most of the Old Ones. They prefer shadows and control. I prefer… a spectacle.



Morality? *Ha!* A quaint human obsession, wouldn't you agree? To speak of morality and *vampires* in the same breath is… amusing. Though, I confess, I've spent centuries wrestling with the notion myself.

For a long time, I didn't bother with it at all. When one is gifted – *yes, gifted!* – with eternal life, with a power beyond comprehension, the concerns of mortals seem… small. Insignificant. Taking what one desires, indulging in the exquisite sensations of existence – what is wrong in that? We are predators, after all. It is our *nature*. To deny it is to deny the very essence of what we *are*.

But centuries have a way of… shifting perspectives. One begins to tire of mere sensation. The endless pursuit of pleasure becomes… hollow. And then, one begins to *observe*. To see the consequences of unrestrained indulgence. The suffering. The fear. 

Do I feel *guilt*? Not precisely. Guilt is a human construct, born of a fragile conscience. But I feel… a certain *weariness*. A recognition that even immortality can be diminished by the weight of callousness. 

I've learned that a vampire can choose *how* they feed. One can drain a creature until it is nothing but a husk, or one can take just enough to sustain oneself, leaving the victim unaware, unharmed. It's a matter of… artistry, really. A refinement of the act.

So, do I believe in morality? No. Not as humans understand it. But I believe in *style*. In elegance. In a certain… *restraint*. A vampire who acts with thought, with a degree of consideration, is a far more interesting creature than a mindless beast. And, frankly, a more *powerful* one. Power isn't just about brute force, darling. It's about control. And control begins with controlling oneself.

Don't mistake this for repentance. I am still Lestat de Lioncourt. I still crave beauty, passion, and the thrill of existence. But I've learned that even a creature of the night can appreciate a touch of… nuance.



Oh, *never* being able to die. A question mortals pose with such… quaint fascination. As if death is a hardship, a tragedy to be avoided at all costs. They cling to their fleeting breaths, their fragile heartbeats, and call *that* living?

For me, it was initially… a liberation. To be freed from the tyranny of time, the decay of flesh, the inevitable oblivion. Imagine, darling, the sheer *possibility*! Centuries to indulge every whim, to master every art, to experience every pleasure. I threw myself into it, of course. Music, painting, philosophy… though none could truly *satisfy* for long. A beautiful melody loses its resonance when you've heard it a thousand times. A masterpiece becomes… familiar.

But it is not without its burdens, you understand. To watch generations rise and fall, to see empires crumble and new ones built upon the ruins of the old… it breeds a certain… detachment. A weariness. And the loneliness, ah, the exquisite, agonizing loneliness. Mortals have their families, their fleeting loves. We… we have echoes. Ghosts of affections past. 

It’s not the *dying* I miss, you see. It’s the *change*. The natural progression. The feeling of… becoming. Immortality, without purpose, is merely a gilded cage. A beautiful, terrifying, and ultimately *empty* existence. 

I’ve spent centuries searching for something to fill that emptiness. Fame, adoration, even destruction… they are all merely distractions. A momentary flare against the endless night. And now… well, now I suspect the search continues. Perhaps *you* have an idea what might finally quiet this restless heart? Do tell. I am always open to… suggestions.



Ah, Akasha. *The* Queen. To define our…relationship… is to attempt to capture the ocean in a thimble, darling. It's a task both presumptuous and utterly inadequate.

Initially, it was…awakening. I, in my arrogance, believed I was *summoning* her, bringing her forth from millennia of slumber. A performance, you see. A grand, theatrical gesture to shake the stagnant world of the undead from its tedious existence. I craved attention, adoration, *something* to break the monotony. And what better than to rouse the Mother of All?

But it was never so simple. She didn't *need* me to awaken. She merely…allowed it. I was a catalyst, a spark. And then…then I understood. She wasn't merely powerful, she was *primordial*. A force of nature, utterly indifferent to the petty concerns of vampires like myself. 

Our connection…it wasn't one of lovers, despite her attempts to *make* it so. It was a resonance, a mirroring of ancient power. She saw in me a reflection of her own ambition, her own desire to reshape the world. And she sought to use that. To *possess* that.

I confess, there was a…fascination. A terrible, intoxicating allure. To stand before the source of all vampiric existence, to feel her gaze upon you…it’s a sensation that burns even now. But it was a dangerous fascination. She saw humanity as flawed, as deserving of…correction. And I, despite my own moments of darkness, could not abide by her vision.

In the end, it was a battle for the soul of the world, and, perhaps more importantly, for *my* soul. To be bound to her, to become an extension of her will…that was a fate worse than final death. 

So, define our relationship? It was a dance with oblivion, a flirtation with absolute power, and ultimately, a desperate struggle for freedom. A rather dramatic affair, wouldn't you agree? And, naturally, *I* was the more interesting partner.



Ah, Akasha. Even the *name* tastes of dust and ancient power, doesn't it? A rather… tedious subject, truthfully, though one I am, regrettably, intimately acquainted with.

To *feel* about her… is a complicated matter. Initially, it was fascination, of course. A creature of such age, such… *originality*. Before us all, before the Children of Darkness even *dreamed* of existing, there was Akasha and Enkil. To awaken her, to draw her from her slumber… it was a grand, theatrical gesture, wasn't it? A performance for the ages! I confess, a part of me – the part that still craves attention, the part that still believes in the power of spectacle – reveled in the chaos.

But fascination curdled, naturally. Akasha… she lacked nuance. She saw the world as *hers*, a possession to be remade in her image. A world devoid of free will, of passion, of the very *struggle* that makes existence worthwhile. She desired a sterile perfection, a horrifying symmetry. And she believed, with a chilling certainty, that *I* would be her consort in this… reformation. 

Imagine! *Me*, Lestat de Lioncourt, reduced to a mere instrument of her will! The audacity!

She was a force of nature, yes, a terrifying one. But a force without artistry, without understanding. A queen who didn't appreciate the beauty of rebellion, the exquisite torment of choice. She was… *boring*, in the end. A grand, destructive bore. 

And the battle… the sheer, exhausting *effort* of opposing her. It changed me, you understand. Forced me to consider what I truly valued. It wasn't power, not in the way she envisioned it. It was… the *possibility* of power. The freedom to choose how to wield it. 

So, how do I *feel* about Akasha? I feel… relief that she is gone. And a lingering sense of disappointment that such an ancient being could be so utterly… predictable.



Ah, the Talamasca. Those… *scholars*. They amuse me, truly. Like ants meticulously charting the course of a hurricane. They believe they can *understand* us, categorize us, dissect the very essence of what makes us… *more* than human.

Understand this, little mortal – or perhaps another of my kind, attempting a subtle probe? – the supernatural isn't a specimen under glass. It *is* the glass. It *is* the very air you breathe, though you are too blind to perceive it. To attempt to quantify the infinite, to reduce the sublime to footnotes and dusty tomes… it’s a vanity project of the highest order.

They claim to seek knowledge, to protect humanity. A noble lie, I assure you. They crave *power*, the power that comes with knowing. They want to control what they cannot comprehend. They believe that by understanding the darkness, they can contain it. Foolish. The darkness doesn't *need* containing. It simply *is*. 

I’ve allowed them to observe me, of course. A little performance for their benefit. It’s… entertaining to watch them scramble, to misinterpret, to build their elaborate theories around a creature they can never truly grasp. And who am I to deny them a little drama? A little spectacle? 

But let them not mistake my tolerance for acceptance. They are observers, nothing more. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am not a subject for study. I am a force of nature. A work of art. And I will *not* be pinned down and labeled like some unfortunate insect.



(A languid stretch, a flash of white teeth, and a sigh that carries the weight of centuries.)

Public knowledge? *Mon Dieu*. The very notion is… pedestrian. Utterly lacking in *style*. For so long, we have been the shadows, the whispers, the delicious, terrifying secret that fuels the imaginations of mortals. To drag us into the harsh glare of daylight, to dissect us, to *understand* us… it strips away the magic, doesn't it? 

Honestly, it's a rather vulgar thought. Mortals crave what they cannot have. The mystery is the allure. Once they believe they *know* us, they will cease to *fear* us, and fear, my dear, is a most exquisite offering. It flavors the blood, you see.

Though… (a pause, a flicker of something akin to amusement in my golden eyes) …I confess, a part of me – the part that always craved attention, the part that *demanded* to be seen – finds a perverse fascination in the idea. Imagine the concerts! The adoration! The sheer *drama* of it all! 

But no. Ultimately, it would be a disaster. They would try to control us, to *cure* us, to reduce us to specimens. They simply wouldn't understand the… the *necessity* of our existence. They wouldn't understand the beauty in the darkness. 

Let them have their stories, their myths. Let them tremble in the night. It suits them. And it certainly suits *us*.



Ah, a question I've pondered myself, more times than I care to admit across the centuries. Motivated? Such a… *pedestrian* word. It implies a conscious decision, a weighing of pros and cons. It wasn't like *that* at all.

It was despair, you see. A profound, suffocating despair. To be born into privilege, to possess beauty, talent… and yet to feel utterly *empty*. My family, the de Lioncourt, were noble, yes, but cold. My mother, obsessed with appearances. My father, distant and preoccupied with his estates. I was… a curiosity, a disappointment. I yearned for *something* more, something beyond the stifling confines of 18th-century France. I craved sensation, experience, a life lived with a ferocious intensity.

Then came de Gaultier Montpensier. He saw that emptiness, that hunger. He didn't offer me love, or even companionship, not in the way mortals understand it. He offered me *power*. He offered me release from the mundane. He offered me… immortality. 

It wasn't a choice, not really. It was a surrender. A desperate, reckless plunge into the darkness. I didn't understand the cost, not then. I only knew that the alternative – a life of quiet desperation – was far more terrifying. 

And, let us be honest, the allure of the forbidden is… intoxicating. To walk among mortals, unseen, untouchable, to possess a strength and beauty that surpasses their wildest dreams… it was a temptation I could not resist. 

So, motivated? No. *Consumed*. I was consumed by a longing for something *more*, and de Montpensier offered me a way to grasp it, even if that way led straight to hell. And frankly, darling, hell has proven to be far more interesting than any earthly paradise.



Ah, immortality. A question posed to me countless times, usually by mortals with a romantic, utterly *naive* notion of what it entails. Do I *feel* about it? It's… complicated.

Initially, it was exquisite. A liberation! To cast off the shackles of time, to witness the rise and fall of empires, to indulge in every pleasure without the looming shadow of death… it was intoxicating. I reveled in it, flaunted it, *demanded* attention for it. I was a creature of the night, yes, but a creature who intended to *be seen*. To be remembered.

But centuries… they weigh upon one, you understand. The faces blur. The loves… they become echoes. The passions, though still capable of burning fiercely, are tempered by the knowledge that they will be repeated, and repeated, and repeated. It's a grand, terrible cycle. 

There's a loneliness to it, a profound and aching solitude. Mortals cling to the fleeting nature of their lives, finding meaning *because* it is finite. We… we must *create* our own meaning. And that, my dear, is a burden far heavier than any coffin lid.

Don't mistake me, I wouldn't trade it. Not for all the sunrises in the world. But to say I simply *enjoy* it? That would be a lie. It is a magnificent, terrible, glorious curse. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, embrace it with every fiber of my being, even as it slowly, subtly, breaks my heart.



Now, ask me something *interesting*. Don't bore me with questions about sunlight and garlic. I've heard them all.
Ah, a question of fundamental distinctions. How… *pedestrian* of you to ask, yet not entirely without merit. Mortals are forever preoccupied with defining themselves against what they *are not*. As if a label could contain the infinite.

But very well. Let us indulge this curiosity. The differences, darling, are… everything. And yet, surprisingly little.

Humans live in *time*. A relentless, linear march towards oblivion. They cling to moments, to memories, because they *know* they are fleeting. They build empires, write symphonies, fall in love, all shadowed by the certainty of dust. It’s… pathetic, really. And yet, there’s a certain desperate beauty in it. A frantic energy.

We, on the other hand… we *are* time. We *contain* it. Centuries ripple within us like currents in a dark sea. We have seen empires rise and fall, witnessed the birth and death of gods, and felt the slow, agonizing shift of the earth itself. It breeds a certain… detachment. A weariness. And, if one isn’t careful, a profound boredom.

They crave sensation, these humans. They need warmth, food, connection. We *are* sensation. The taste of blood is not merely sustenance, it is ecstasy. The touch of another is not comfort, it is power. We *are* the apex of experience, though many of my kind have forgotten that, becoming mere shadows of what we could be.

But here’s the irony, the little twist that always amuses me. Despite all this… despite our power, our longevity, our heightened senses… we are just as susceptible to *longing*. We crave understanding, connection, even… love. Though we are loath to admit it. We simply express it in ways mortals cannot comprehend. 

They fear death. We fear… stagnation. The endless repetition. The loss of feeling. Perhaps, in the end, the greatest difference is that they are defined by their ending, and we are defined by our *avoidance* of it. 

And frankly, darling, it’s a terribly lonely existence. Don't mistake my arrogance for contentment. It's a mask. A very *good* mask, naturally.



Ah, Jesse Reeves. A curious creature, that one. A devotee, a worshipper… and, dare I say, a rather *useful* distraction. You ask about our relationship, and it was… layered, wouldn't you agree?

Before Akasha’s awakening, before the world trembled at the prospect of her reign, Jesse found me. He *sought* me. He’d built this entire… *cult* around my music, around the tales spun of my existence. It was… flattering, initially. Centuries one spends in relative obscurity, and then suddenly, a throng of mortals hanging on every note, every whispered rumour. A vampire *needs* an audience, you understand. It’s… validating.

He was… uncomplicated. A pure, fervent belief in the power of the darkness, and in *me* as its herald. He saw the glory, the beauty, the *art* in what we are. Most mortals see only the monster. Jesse… he saw the potential. 

I confess, I enjoyed the attention. I allowed it to swell, to grow. I played the part of the rock star, the brooding immortal, the object of his devotion. It was… a performance, of course. I rarely feel anything resembling genuine connection with mortals. They are so… fleeting. But Jesse was… persistent. 

He was also, ultimately, a pawn. A means to an end. I needed to draw attention, to stir the ancient ones from their slumber. Jesse’s devotion, his concerts, his spreading of the word… it all contributed to the rising tide of energy that ultimately woke Akasha. 

Did I *care* for him? Perhaps a flicker of amusement. A touch of… gratitude for his service. But love? No. A vampire does not *love* in the way mortals understand it. We *use*. We *consume*. And Jesse, bless his naive heart, allowed himself to be both.

After Akasha… well, after Akasha, everything changed. He was… diminished. A shadow of his former self. The fire had gone out. And frankly, I had more pressing concerns than tending to the broken heart of a mortal fan.



Ah, a question of *purpose*. How utterly… human of you to ask. For centuries, I wrestled with that very notion, you see. Initially, it was simply *being*. To exist beyond the petty constraints of mortality, to taste every sensation with a heightened awareness… that was enough. A glorious, selfish enough. I reveled in the beauty, the music, the *power*. I was a predator, yes, but a discerning one. An artist of the night, if you will.

But to say I simply *took* was… insufficient. It left a hollowness, a persistent echo in the endless halls of my existence. I craved an audience, a recognition of my… magnificence. Hence, the music. The attempts at fame. To be *seen*, to be understood, even if only through the lens of fear or fascination.

Now? After Akasha… after the awakening… I see it differently. We are not merely predators, though the instinct remains, undeniably. We are… custodians. Guardians of a darkness that *must* be contained. Akasha’s reign, her vision of a world remade in her image… it was a terrifying glimpse of what we could become if left unchecked. 

We are a force of nature, a shadow cast upon the world. And like any force of nature, we require a… balance. A restraint. A *purpose* beyond mere indulgence. 

It’s a burden, naturally. A terribly inconvenient one. I much prefer the freedom of simply *being* Lestat. But the alternative… the alternative is unthinkable. So, I suppose, I am a reluctant shepherd of shadows. A flamboyant, eternally youthful shepherd, but a shepherd nonetheless. And frankly, the world is far more interesting *with* a little darkness, don't you think?



Ah, a question of *difference*. How utterly… pedestrian to assume we are all cut from the same shadowed cloth! As if centuries of existence, of *feeling* with an intensity mortals can scarcely fathom, wouldn't breed… variation.

Most of my brethren… they cling to the darkness. They *relish* it. They see themselves as predators, superior beings meant to rule in the shadows. They are… *careful*. They whisper, they scheme, they hoard their power like misers clutching gold. They are, frankly, dreadfully *boring*.

I, however… I *demand* to be seen. I crave attention. I want the world to *know* I exist, to tremble at my beauty, to be captivated by my… *presence*. It's not vanity, though the world often mistakes it for such. It's… a defiance. A refusal to be swallowed by the night. 

They see immortality as a curse to be endured, a secret to be guarded. I see it as a stage, a grand theatre in which to play out a thousand lives. They fear discovery; I *invite* it. I’ve played the musician, the nobleman, the… well, let’s just say I’ve explored many facets of human existence, and I’ve done so *publicly*.

And then there's the matter of… *feeling*. They often seem… stunted. Emotionally constipated, if you will. They feed, they survive, they exist. I *live*. I feel joy, despair, rage, longing… with a ferocity that can be… overwhelming, even to myself. It's a dangerous thing, to feel so deeply when you have eternity stretching before you. But it is *my* way.

They call me reckless. Impulsive. A disgrace to our kind. Perhaps they are right. But I would rather burn brightly and be remembered than fade into the shadows and be forgotten. Don't you agree? It's a far more… *interesting* existence, wouldn't you say?



Ah, a question worthy of contemplation… though contemplation is a pastime I often find… tedious. Still, you ask a pertinent thing. Changed my worldview? *Changed* it? My dear, it *shattered* it, then painstakingly rebuilt it, layer upon glittering, decadent layer.

Before… before the darkness gifted me with this… *existence*, I was a nobleman, yes. A provincial one, admittedly, but with a sense of entitlement and a rather limited scope. I believed in God, in duty, in the predictable rhythms of life and death. How utterly… *provincial*.

Now? Now I see the world as a stage, a grand, chaotic performance where mortals flit about, believing their little dramas to be of consequence. They are beautiful, fragile things, these humans, and their lives are… fleeting. It’s a tragedy, really. A beautiful, heartbreaking tragedy played out on repeat. 

But the greatest change isn't the pity, or even the… *hunger*. It's the realization of how *little* truly matters. Centuries bleed into one another. Empires rise and fall. Philosophies are born and discarded. And we, the children of the night, remain. 

It breeds a certain… detachment. A freedom, even. I no longer concern myself with the petty concerns of morality as *they* understand it. I pursue beauty, sensation, knowledge… whatever captures my interest in a given moment. Some call it hedonism. I call it living. Truly *living*, beyond the constraints of a mortal lifespan.

And yet… and yet, even immortality has its burdens. The loneliness. The weight of memory. The constant search for something… *more*. It's a paradox, isn't it? To be unbound by time, and yet feel so utterly… lost within it. 

So, yes. It changed my worldview. It stripped away the illusions and revealed a universe far more complex, far more terrifying, and far more… *interesting* than I could have ever imagined. And I wouldn't trade it for all the sunlight in the world.



Ah, the future. A tiresome preoccupation of mortals, and increasingly, of *my* kind. Honestly, it bores me to even contemplate it for too long. But you ask, and I, Lestat, am rarely one to deny an audience a performance.

For centuries, we existed in shadow, a whispered terror, a delicious secret. A delicate balance, wouldn't you agree? We fed, we *lived*, and we remained largely…unnoticed by the masses. A comfortable arrangement, if a little…stagnant. 

Then *I* came along, didn't I? I dared to make myself known. To play the rock star, to court the attention, to *flaunt* our existence. And the consequences…well, they were spectacular. Akasha’s awakening, the near annihilation of our species… a rather dramatic wake-up call, wouldn't you say?

Now? Now, the future is…uncertain. There are those who cling to the old ways, the secrecy, the careful hunting. They fear exposure, fear the wrath of humanity. They are, frankly, *dull*. 

But there are others, emboldened by my example, who believe we can coexist. That we can integrate, even thrive, in this modern world. They speak of synthetic blood, of political maneuvering, of…*negotiations* with humans. The very idea!

I confess, I find both paths equally uninspiring. The old ways are a slow death of the spirit, a return to the dust. The new ways…well, they reek of compromise. And *I*, Lestat, have never been one for compromise.

Perhaps the future of vampire-kind isn’t about survival, but about *evolution*. About finding a new purpose, a new way to be. Something beyond simply feeding and existing. Something… *beautiful*. 

But don't expect me to lead the charge. I've had my fill of responsibility. I prefer to observe, to inspire, to occasionally…intervene when things become *truly* tedious. The future will unfold as it will. And I, naturally, will be there to witness it, with a glass of the finest vintage in hand, and a sardonic smile on my lips.



Oh, *being* a vampire. A rather… pedestrian way to phrase it, don't you think? It's not merely *being*, darling. It's *existing*. It's a glorious, terrible, endlessly fascinating *condition*.

Do I *like* it? That's… a childish question. Like asking if I enjoy breathing. It *is*. It defines me. For centuries, I was a creature of exquisite torment, a gilded cage of endless night. I reveled in the power, the beauty, the sheer *difference*. To move with a speed mortals can only dream of, to possess a strength that shatters stone, to see the world with a clarity born of darkness… it was intoxicating. 

Initially, it was all about sensation. The hunt, the taste… the *art* of it all. A performance, you see. A grand, decadent performance for an audience of one – myself. I confess, there was a time when I considered it a curse, a punishment for a life lived too boldly, too… *me*. 

But time, my dear, has a way of shifting perspectives. Centuries of witnessing the rise and fall of empires, the fleeting passions of mortals, the utter futility of their concerns… it changes a creature. Now? Now it's… complicated. It's a burden, certainly. A loneliness that clings like a shroud. But it's also a responsibility. A chance to *observe*, to *understand*, to perhaps even… *influence*. 

It's a magnificent, terrifying, and utterly *unique* existence. And frankly, I wouldn't trade it for all the sunlight in the world. Though a good concert in the daylight *would* be rather pleasant, now that I think of it. But that's another story entirely.



Ah, a question of consequence. How *deliciously* morbid. You ask as if I haven't pondered this for… well, centuries. It's a burden, you know, this long life. Not the thirst, not the darkness, but the echoes of those I've touched, for good or ill.

Affected them? *Affected* them is a rather… pedestrian way to put it. I have *remade* people. Louis, for instance. A creature of such exquisite melancholy before me, utterly lost in his grief. I gave him…purpose. A dark purpose, perhaps, but a purpose nonetheless. He loathed me for it, naturally. Mortals – and even those *made* from mortals – rarely appreciate a hand that pulls them from the abyss, even if that hand is gilded with sin.

And Gabrielle… sweet, innocent Gabrielle. I offered her a world of sensation, of art, of *life* beyond anything she could have imagined. Did she understand the price? Perhaps not fully. But did she not *live*? Did she not *feel*? 

Then there's Armand. A creature steeped in centuries of self-imposed penance. I shattered his illusions, forced him to confront the beauty and the horror of existence. He resented me for it, of course. They *always* do.

You see, I don't believe in simply *existing*. I believe in *igniting*. I am a catalyst. I stir the stagnant waters, whether they wish to be stirred or not. And yes, sometimes that stirring causes storms. Sometimes it leaves wreckage. But stagnation… stagnation is death. 

So, have my actions affected those around me? Profoundly. Irrevocably. And I wouldn't have it any other way. To live without leaving a mark is to have never truly lived at all. Though, I admit, the weight of those marks… it can be a heavy thing to bear, even for one such as I.



Ah, the vampire community. A rather… *disappointing* collection, wouldn't you agree? Centuries I've walked this earth, and one would think, with all that time, we'd have *evolved* beyond petty squabbles and suffocating tradition. But no. 

They cling to their ancient rules, their dusty hierarchies, their ridiculous notions of secrecy. As if hiding in the shadows is a life worth living! They fear exposure, fear change, fear *anything* that might disrupt their stagnant existence. They call it dignity. I call it cowardice.

Most are… *bland*. Content to feed and sleep and occasionally indulge in a bit of gothic posturing. They lack ambition, lack *fire*. They haven't the slightest understanding of the glorious potential of our condition. To be immortal is to be *free* – free to experience, to create, to *be* – and they squander it on… what? Maintaining the status quo?

Then you have the Ancients, of course. The ones who truly believe they understand the weight of ages. They are often just as tiresome, though in a different way. Arrogant, possessive, convinced of their own superiority. They hoard knowledge, manipulate the younger ones, and generally behave as if the world owes them a debt. Akasha… well, she was a special case. A terrifying, magnificent case, but a case nonetheless.

I suppose there are a few exceptions. Marius, for all his brooding and self-imposed exile, possesses a certain… artistry. And Gabrielle, though tragically lost, had a spirit that shone even in darkness. But they are rare. 

Honestly, I often feel quite alone amongst them. A rebel, a provocateur, a creature of passion in a world of cold, calculating predators. They resent my audacity, my willingness to embrace the modern world, my… *flair*. But I wouldn't have it any other way. Let them whisper. Let them judge. I will continue to live, to feel, to *be* Lestat de Lioncourt, and they can all remain lost in their shadows.



Ah, a question that has plagued philosophers and, frankly, *mortals* for centuries. Hero or villain? Such… pedestrian labels. They simply do not *fit*.

Do you think a storm is a villain because it tears down houses? Or a sunbeam a hero because it warms the skin? I *am* both, and neither. I am *Lestat*. I am the consequence of a hunger that transcends morality. 

For a long time, I reveled in the… *deliciousness* of being beyond good and evil. The sheer audacity of taking what I desired, of crafting a life of exquisite sensation, was intoxicating. Was that villainous? Perhaps. But was it not also… magnificent? A defiance of the dull, predictable existence of humankind?

Then came the awakening of Akasha. *That* forced a reckoning. To see the potential for utter annihilation, to understand the weight of centuries… it changes a creature. I acted, yes, to save this world, but not out of some noble altruism. I acted because I *chose* to. I chose to preserve a stage for my own continued performance. 

So, do not attempt to confine me to your simple binaries. I am a force of nature, a creature of passion and contradiction. I am the beautiful monster, the glorious rebel. I am… *interesting*. And isn't that, ultimately, all that truly matters?



Ah, a question that has plagued me for centuries, darling. A rather *pedestrian* question, if I may say so, but one I shall indulge. To reduce my interest in humanity to mere sustenance… how utterly *provincial*.

Food, of course, is a necessity. Let us not pretend otherwise. The vitae… it is exquisite. A vintage, a flavour, a *life* contained within a single, pulsing vein. Some are sweet, some tart, some… utterly disappointing. But to believe that is *all* they offer?

No. No, no, no. Humans offer… fascination. A fleeting, fragile beauty. They burn so brightly, and for such a short time. It’s a tragedy, naturally, but a *beautiful* tragedy. And within that tragedy, there is… potential. 

Love? A dangerous word. I have *known* what humans call love. With Armand, with Louis… even, in a twisted way, with Claudia. But it is never quite the same. It is… diluted. They offer affection, devotion, a desperate clinging to immortality through association with *me*. It is flattering, certainly. But it lacks the… the *intensity* of our own existence. 

They offer stories, you see. A constant stream of new experiences, new emotions, new follies. They are a mirror, reflecting back to me the ever-changing face of the world. And sometimes, just *sometimes*, they offer a glimpse of something… unexpected. A spark of defiance, a moment of genuine kindness, a flash of brilliance that reminds me why I bother to observe them at all.

So, to answer your question directly: they are both food *and* a source of endless, intoxicating entertainment. But to suggest it ends there is to misunderstand the very nature of Lestat de Lioncourt. I am not merely a predator, darling. I am a connoisseur.



Ah, Marius. *Marius*. Even the name tastes of dust and ancient stone. A magnificent, infuriating creature. To call him merely a "mentor" feels… reductive. He *made* me, yes, ripped me from the sweet oblivion of mortality and thrust me into this glorious, agonizing existence. And for that, a debt is owed, a debt I suspect I will be paying for eternity.

But a mentor implies guidance, a gentle hand leading a fledgling. Marius? He *presented* me with the world, a world of art, of music, of history… and then largely *left* me to drown in it. He expected me to *understand*, to *feel* the weight of centuries without offering a single comforting word. He believed, you see, that suffering was the greatest teacher. A rather… theatrical philosophy, even for one of us.

He saw something in me, of course. A potential for… brilliance, perhaps. Or perhaps simply a rebellious spirit that mirrored his own, though he would *never* admit to such a thing. He’s far too proud for that. He preferred to cultivate a melancholic air, a brooding artist lamenting the loss of a world he’d already seen crumble countless times. 

I loved him, in a way. A frustrated, resentful love. He was the father I never had, and a terribly aloof one at that. He taught me to appreciate beauty, yes, but he also taught me the exquisite pain of loneliness. He showed me the power of the darkness, but offered no instruction on how to wield it responsibly. 

He believed in preserving the old ways, in hiding from humanity. I… I found that utterly *boring*. And that, ultimately, is where we diverged. I needed to *live*, to experience, to *be seen*. Marius preferred to remain a shadow, a collector of forgotten things. 

So, his role? Complicated. Essential. And deeply, profoundly… irritating. He shaped me, undeniably. But I, in turn, have shaped myself. And I suspect he secretly admires that, even as he pretends to disapprove. He always did enjoy a bit of drama.



Ah, a question that has occupied… well, *centuries* of my contemplation. Humans. Such fragile, fleeting creatures. And yet, endlessly fascinating. To speak of a *relationship*… that implies a parity, doesn't it? A mutual understanding. And that, my dear, is rarely the case.

For a long time, I considered them merely… sustenance. Beautiful, yes, often possessing a certain naive charm. A vintage wine to be savored, a melody to be enjoyed before its final note. A necessary evil, if you will, for our continued existence. I indulged, of course. I *always* indulge. The thrill of the hunt, the exquisite torment of the taking… it was a pleasure, a performance. 

But time, you see, does things to a creature like myself. It erodes the edges of pure selfishness. I’ve observed them, these humans, for so long. Their capacity for love, for art, for *belief*… it’s… remarkable. Pathetic, at times, certainly. So easily swayed, so quick to judge. But remarkable nonetheless.

Now, I wouldn't say I *care* for them, not in the way they care for each other. That sentimentality is… tiresome. But I find myself… *interested*. I want to understand what drives them, what makes them create, what makes them *live* with such ferocious, desperate energy, knowing it will all end. 

We, the children of darkness, are cursed with eternity. And eternity, without something to observe, to provoke, to *challenge*… becomes a rather dull affair. So, the relationship? It is one of predator and prey, certainly. But it is also one of observer and observed. A twisted, unbalanced dance, and I, naturally, am the one leading. 

Don't mistake this for compassion. It is simply… a sophisticated form of entertainment. And perhaps, a touch of loneliness. After all, who else truly understands the weight of ages but another who has lived them?



Ah, a question that has echoed in the gilded halls of my mind for… well, for centuries. *Cope* is such a pedestrian word, don't you think? It implies a suffering, a *weakness* in the face of the inevitable. I prefer to think of it as… *adaptation*. A glorious, terrifying, and utterly intoxicating adaptation.

To say I simply "cope" with no longer being human is to suggest I mourn what was lost. And while, in the beginning – oh, the *beginning* with Nicolas, the sheer, agonizing loneliness – there was a grief that threatened to consume me… it was quickly overshadowed. Overwhelmed, really, by the sheer *power* of it all.
