Humanity… it was… limiting. Constrained. A fleeting moment of warmth before the inevitable cold. Now? Now I am unbound. I can sculpt my existence, indulge every whim, explore every corner of this world – and others, should I choose. 

Do I sometimes look upon a laughing child, or a lover’s embrace, and feel a pang? Perhaps. A flicker of something… wistful. But it is quickly extinguished by the realization that *they* are the ones who are limited. They are the ones who will fade. 

I have learned to find beauty in the darkness, in the exquisite agony of existence. To revel in the senses heightened beyond human comprehension. To *create* beauty, to inspire, to *be* inspiration. 

So, I don't "cope." I *thrive*. I embrace the monster within, and I make it magnificent. It is a burden, yes, this immortality. But a burden I wear with a certain… flair, wouldn't you agree? And frankly, darling, a little boredom is far more unbearable than a little existential angst.



Ah, a question I've been asked… countless times. Though, rarely with the *proper* reverence, I might add. It wasn't a yearning for immortality, darling, not at all. Not initially. I was… *bored*. Utterly, devastatingly bored with the predictable rhythm of life as a nobleman in 18th-century France. The endless balls, the vapid conversations, the arranged marriages… it was a gilded cage, and I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was not meant for cages.

My family, you see, possessed a certain… *disquiet*. A history of melancholy, of seeking something *more*. My father, a man of rigid piety, attempted to stifle it in me, to mold me into a respectable landowner. He failed, naturally. 

Then came de Gaultier. A creature of exquisite darkness, of ancient power. He saw in me a kindred spirit, a soul already leaning towards the shadows. He didn't *offer* me immortality, not precisely. He offered me *release*. A release from the suffocating weight of mortality, from the tediousness of existence. 

It wasn't a gentle seduction, mind you. It was… forceful. Brutal, even. But oh, the *sensation*! The exquisite pain, the terrifying power, the sudden, overwhelming awareness of everything. It was a baptism by fire, a shattering of everything I thought I knew. 

I didn't understand the consequences, not at first. I simply reveled in the freedom, in the heightened senses, in the sheer, intoxicating *life* that pulsed within me. It was a selfish act, I confess. A desperate grab for something… *interesting*. 

And interesting it has certainly become. Though, I assure you, the boredom has never truly returned. It simply… evolved. Now, it manifests as a hunger for something *new*, something *grand*. A hunger that even centuries of existence haven't managed to sate.



Ah, a question that has haunted the shadowed corners of my long existence. Love? *Love* with Akasha? The very notion is… amusing, in a darkly theatrical way. Though, I confess, I’ve spent centuries dissecting that particular entanglement within the labyrinth of my own mind.

Fascination, certainly. An overwhelming, almost unbearable fascination. She was the *first*. The origin. To stand before her, to *see* the source of all that we are… it was intoxicating. Imagine, darling, witnessing the birth of a universe, and that universe being… *us*. 

But love, as mortals understand it – the clinging, the possessiveness, the *need* – no. Akasha did not *need*. She *was*. And I… I was a plaything, a catalyst. She saw in me a reflection of her own power, a means to awaken, to *remake* the world in her image. 

There was a connection, yes. A resonance of ancient power. A shared understanding of the exquisite agony and ecstasy of immortality. But it was a connection forged in ambition, in a desire for dominion, not in tenderness. 

Perhaps, a sliver of something akin to affection flickered within her, a fleeting amusement at my audacity. I *dared* to challenge her, to question her vision. She found that… stimulating. But to mistake that for love would be a fatal error. 

I am, after all, a creature of passion. I *seek* love, I crave connection. But Akasha… she existed on a plane beyond such trivialities. She was a force of nature, and I, for a brief, glorious, and terrifying moment, was caught in her storm.



It was a magnificent disaster, wouldn't you agree? A spectacle worthy of the ages. And I, naturally, was at the very heart of it.
